A B S T R A C T 10 

The Barra de Itiúba Formation (Hauterivian-Barremian) records deposition in deltaic 11 

and lacustrine environments accumulated in the early syn-rift stage of the Sergipe-12 

Alagoas Basin, northeastern Brazil. Detailed facies description in thirteen outcrops 13 

allowed the identification of 17 facies, grouped in seven facies associations 14 

interpreted as recording different depositional processes in proximal to distal 15 

environments (delta plain, delta front, prodelta, and lacustrine). Detailed sequence 16 

stratigraphic studies carried out in two outcrops (6, 7) led to the definition of six (four 17 

complete) high-frequency sequences (probably 4
th

 order level) intimately linked to rift 18 

tectonic and climatic controls. Two sequences in the studied succession were 19 

incomplete, but four sequences display depositional trends that reflect variation in the 20 

rate of creation/destruction of accommodation space, amount of sediment supply 21 

(A/S ratio), and lake base level. Depositional sequence begin with a retrogradational 22 

portion marked by lacustrine transgression (bounded at the top by maximum flooding 23 

surface), in which proximal delta plain deposits passes upward to distal delta front 24 

and prodelta-lacustrine facies. This retrogradacional trend characterize a base level 25 

rise of the lake which result in renewable creation of accommodation with low 26 

sediment supply. Then, a progradational coarsening-upward succession (CU) 27 



2  

overlies the maximum flooding surface, and represent the “filled phase”, when 28 

sediment supply will gradually increase relative to available accommodation space. 29 

This succession is represented by deltaic progradation, in which distal facies 30 

(lacustrine, prodelta) give progressively way to proximal delta front systems (delta 31 

plain with proximal delta front). Paleocurrent data analyzed in relation to the main 32 

structural elements defining grabens and half-grabens showed the dominance of 33 

transverse drainage over axial in the study area. 34 

Keywords: Lower Cretaceous; Sergipe-Alagoas Basin; stratigraphy; syn-rift deposits; continental 35 

environments; regional reconstructions. 36 

1. Introduction 37 

Since the 1990s, many authors have proposed models for the stratigraphic 38 

evolution of rift basins based on tectonic basin geometry and sedimentary response 39 

using the A/S (accommodation to supply) ratio, corresponding to the dominance or 40 

not of accommodation space over sediment supply for each period of basin infilling 41 

(Prosser, 1993; Bosence, 1998; Gawthorpe and Leeder, 2000; Morley, 2002; Kuchle 42 

and Scherer, 2010). Recently, some studies have detailed stratigraphic cycle 43 

observed in rift basins in term of depositional trends and deposit environments 44 

(Martins-Neto, 2000, 2007, 2009), but infilling patterns and the relationship between 45 

tectonic and climatic factors are yet poorly understood (Morley, 2002). Depending on 46 

the tectonic evolution, climate, accommodation space, and sediment supply, the 47 

entire rift succession may develop different depositional environments over time and 48 

space. Sedimentary filling in a rift is predominantly carried out by alluvial systems 49 

connected to a lake. Frequently, these two depositional environments are 50 

interconnected with a deltaic system, formed during the sedimentary discharge by 51 

fluvial channels in lake (Elliot, 1986). Deltas are very common in rifts, and can be 52 

subdivided in three environments: (a) Delta plain, recognizable by the distribution of 53 



3  

several single fluvial channels (Battacharya, 2006), associated with many humid sub-54 

environments; (b) Delta front, reflecting the place where the fluvial channel 55 

discharged into the lake, associated with thick sand bars along steep slopes (Elliot, 56 

1986); and (c) Prodelta, where fine sediments (massive clays and silts, more or less 57 

bioturbated) transported by suspension settle.  58 

Numerous well and seismic studies of the rift phase in the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin 59 

have been carried out, mainly in the onshore portion of São Miguel dos Campos, 60 

Alagoas Sub-basin. Data interpretation allowed to identify the main sedimentary 61 

sequences of the Barra de Itiúba Formation (Lower Cretaceous) syn-rift deposits 62 

(Borba, 2009, 2011). However, this unit is poorly exposed and very few sections have 63 

been studied and documented in the outcrop area (Garcia, 1991; Barreiro, 2004; 64 

Nowatzki et al., 2006). A prospecting study identified new outcrops in this region, 65 

allowing for the collection of field data to augment the knowledge on the stratigraphy 66 

and facies architecture of the Barra de Itiúba Formation.  67 

 The main objective of this paper was to understand the formation and controlling 68 

mechanisms of early rift deposits in the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin, especially in the 69 

outcrop area (Japoatã-Penedo High), through a detailed study of sedimentology and 70 

stratigraphic architecture of the Barra de Itiúba Formation. Specific goals included: 71 

(1) the identification of facies and facies associations that represent specific 72 

depositional environments; (2) the identification of key stratigraphic surfaces, and 73 

higher frequency sequences; and (3) the analysis of facies architecture and 74 

paleocurrent directions to understand the provenance and sediment input in the 75 

study area.  76 

2. Geological setting 77 

The Sergipe-Alagoas Basin, located on the Brazilian eastern margin (Fig. 1A), 78 

covers an onshore area of 13,000 km² of sediments and an offshore portion of 79 



4  

32,760 km² (Mohriak, 2003). This basin was formed as a result from the evolution of 80 

an asymmetric rift elongated in NNE/SSW directions and limited in the south by the 81 

Vaza-Barris fault system and by the Maragogi High in the north (Campos Neto et al., 82 

2007). Feijo (1994) separated the basin in two parts: the Sergipe and the Alagoas 83 

Basins, structurally separated by the Japoatã-Penedo High. However, according to 84 

other studies (Campos Neto et al., 2007), this structural complex is located in the 85 

onshore portion only and does not extend to the Charneira lower block, leaving 86 

doubts about the basin sub-division. In the study area, extension was mostly 87 

controlled by the border normal fault, called Propriá Fault (Destro, 1995), associated 88 

with other NE/SW-oriented normal faults, forming graben and half-graben systems. 89 

Within the extensional compartment, two major NW/SE-oriented faults (nearly 90 

perpendicular to the strike of the border fault) can be identified (Fig. 1B). The last 91 

have been interpreted as normal release faults (Destro, 1995), very common in rift 92 

systems.   93 

 The stratigraphic record in the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin is the most complete 94 

succession among the Brazilian continental margins, reflecting different phases of 95 

subsidence (Bizzi et al., 2003): (a) the Syneclise phase record a Gondwanan 96 

intracratonic basin filled by Carboniferous glacial, subaquatic and Permian deltaic-97 

desertic deposits; (b) the Pre-Rift Supersequence (Jurassic-Berriasian) is 98 

characterized by crustal subsidence within the Afro-Brazilian Depression; (c) the Rift 99 

Supersequence (Berriasian to Aptian) reflects the stage of mechanical subsidence; 100 

and d) the Post-Rift Supersequence (Aptian) marked the onset and dominance of 101 

thermal subsidence, during which the first major marine incursion took place in the 102 

latest Aptian. The studied succession belong to the Rift Supersequence. 103 

 Stratigraphically, the Pre-rift Supersequence is composed of lacustrine sediments 104 

from the Bananeiras Formation, fluvio-deltaic deposits of the Candeiro Formation, 105 



5  

and finally the Serraria Formation and Caioba Sandstone filling the depression with 106 

fluvial braided channel deposits.  107 

 According to Campos Neto et al (2007), the Rift Supersequence, which began 108 

142 Ma ago (Berriasian), is divided in different sub-sequences, from base to top 109 

called K10-K20, K34-K36, K38, and K40. Each sub-sequence corresponds to 110 

tectono-sedimentary episodes (2
th

 or 3
th

-order level) that formed the bulk of 111 

sedimentation during the rift extension (Table 1). The accumulation of the lacustrine 112 

deposits of the Feliz Deserto Formation (K10-K20) marks the beginning of the syn-rift 113 

filling. The focus of this study is the fluvio-deltaic and lacustrine deposits of the Barra 114 

de Itiúba and Penedo Formations (K34-K36) that overlie the Feliz Deserto Formation 115 

and correspond to the second major tectonic pulse of the syn-rift phase, 116 

characterized by the beginning of the establishment of graben and/or half-graben 117 

systems (Chagas et al., 2003). Separating these formations, the “Pre-Aratu 118 

Unconformity” represents an estimated 5-Ma hiatus in sedimentation (Galm and 119 

Santos, 1994) and is related to rift propagation in the Valanginian to Hauterivian 120 

transition (Bueno, 2004). The main depocenters are located in the Alagoas Sub-121 

basin, where some areas have accumulated around 2,000 meters of sediments 122 

(Borba, 2009). The proximal portion of sequence K34-K36 is largely dominated by 123 

the fluvial sandstones of the Penedo Formation, while the mid-distal area is 124 

represented by deltaic-lacustrine deposits of the Barra de Itiúba Formation. During 125 

that time, the ruptile efforts were mainly located in the Sergipe Sub-basin, where 126 

proximal, conglomeratic sandstones of the Rio Pitanga Formation were deposited 127 

very close to the active normal fault (Campos Neto et al., 2007). The end of the 128 

sequence (Upper Barremian) recorded the formation of a well-developed lake with 129 

maximum lake (base) level. Sequence K38 (Aptian), represented by the Pitanga 130 

Formation in the Sergipe Sub-basin, Poção Formation, Coqueiro Seco Formation, 131 



6  

and Morro do Chaves Formation represents the beginning of the third tectonic pulse, 132 

which increased in intensity throughout the basin. Due to the high accommodation 133 

space created by subsidence, accompanied with high rate of sediment supply, the 134 

associated thick deposits are mainly alluvial (Pitanga and Poção Formations) and 135 

deltaic (Coqueiro Seco Formation). Meanwhile, the distal domain was dominated by 136 

the accumulation of carbonates from the Morro de Chaves Formation (Campos Neto 137 

et al., 2007). The last rift sequence K40 (Aptian), resulting of the fourth and latest 138 

tectonic pulse, when the tectonic intensity reached its maximum, is composed of 139 

sandy-evaporitic sediments of the Maceió Formation, along with the Rio Pitanga and 140 

Poção Formations. According to Arienti (1996), this sequence reflects deposition in 141 

more arid climatic conditions at the end of the Syn-Rift Supersequence. 142 

3. Study area and methods 143 

 The studied sections of the Barra de Itiúba Formation are located at northern 144 

Sergipe Basin and southern Alagoas Basin, along the São Francisco River and in the 145 

vicinity of the Japoatã High (Fig. 1B).  146 

Thirteen stratigraphic sections with thicknesses variable between 5.4 and 29.7 m 147 

were measured and analyzed in detail, resulting in the construction of lithologic logs 148 

at 1:100 scale. Facies analysis in the logged sections was based on lithofacies 149 

description following Miall (1978), systematic measurement of paleocurrent directions 150 

in cross-stratified and ripple-laminated sandstones, and construction of a gamma-ray 151 

log for four sections using a hand-held gamma spectrometer. Facies description 152 

included color, grain size, roundness, sorting, detrital composition, bed geometry, 153 

sedimentary structures and fossil content. In addition, two-dimensional panels were 154 

made from photomosaics to reconstruct geometries and architectural elements of the 155 

deposits and structural maps were compiled to interpret sediment input routes.  156 

4. Facies analysis 157 



7  

 Seventeen lithofacies were identified in the Barra de Itiúba Formation in the 158 

study area. They are summarized in Table 2 and illustrated in Fig. 2, 3. The Barra de 159 

Itiúba Formation is composed dominantly of quartzose sandstones, and 160 

subordinately heterolites, mudstones and sandy conglomerates. Texturally, the sand 161 

is very fine- to coarse-grained (mostly fine-grained), moderately- to well-sorted, with 162 

sub-angular to rounded grains. Quartz granules are common in massive sandstones 163 

and near the base of cross-bedded sets. Heterolites are mainly composed of very 164 

fine-grained sandstones, locally with ripple cross-lamination, intercalated with 165 

massive siltstones. Mudstones are commonly greenish to gray, massive, or 166 

laminated. Conglomerates are mostly massive, matrix-supported, with sub-angular to 167 

sub-rounded granules to pebbles (mostly granules). Compositionally the gravel is 168 

composed dominantly of quartz and mud intraclasts, and, subordinately, feldspar and 169 

rock fragments. Stratified, bioclastic conglomerates occur locally. 170 

5.  Facies associations 171 

 The lithofacies identified in the Barra de Itiúba Formation were grouped into seven 172 

facies associations (F.A.): (1) Braided distributary channel; (2) Distributary channel; 173 

(3) Interdistributary bay; (4) Proximal delta front; (5) Distal delta front; (6) Prodelta; 174 

and (7) Lacustrine. 175 

5.1. Braided distributary channel facies association 176 

5.1.1. Description 177 

 This facies association (Fig. 4) consists of several sandstones bodies up to 7.4 m 178 

thick, composed mainly of fine to coarse-grained sandstones with trough cross-179 

stratification (St) and, subordinately, low-angle cross-stratification (Sl). Trough cross-180 

stratified sandy (Gt) and massive, matrix-supported (Gmm) conglomerates cover the 181 

basal erosive surface. Conglomerates are mostly thin (<50 cm thick), largely 182 

represented by a scoured erosive surface (<15 cm) with sub-angular quartz granules 183 



8  

to pebbles. Laterally, the conglomerates can extend for more than 60 m, and they are 184 

overlain by trough cross-bedded sets (St) with sheet geometry, extending laterally for 185 

tens to hundreds meters. Internally, the sand-body succession shows decimetric- to 186 

metric-thick sets, separated by sub-horizontal erosive surface. Paleocurrent patterns 187 

of trough cross-bedded sets (St) show a transport direction close or equal to the 188 

basal erosive conglomerate (Gt, Gmm). 189 

5.1.2. Interpretation 190 

  The sub-horizontal erosive surface marked by quartz granules that bound the 191 

base of large-scale cross-strata represent reactivation surfaces resulting from 192 

episodic (climatic?) variations in current strength and/or sediment supply and 193 

oscillations in river discharge (Fig. 4).  The occurrence of thin, erosive 194 

conglomerates, commonly overlying plurimetric convoluted (Sd) and trough cross-195 

stratified (St) proximal deltaic sandstones followed by the deposition of amalgamated 196 

large cross-strata with reactivation surfaces arranged in stacked decimetric- to 197 

metric-scale sets, suggests deposition in fluvial channels. The vertical association of 198 

these bodies on delta front deposits (described below),  the lack of well-defined 199 

fining-upwards cycles, the low dispersion of paleocurrent directions, the sheet-like 200 

geometry of the sand bodies, composed mainly of medium-to coarse-grained, 201 

moderately sorted sandstones, and the absence of fine-grained interdistributary bay 202 

sediments suggest a deposition in braided distributary fluvial channel. The sheet-like 203 

geometry of the sandstones and the predominance of cross-bedding suggests a 204 

relatively highly mobile and a perennial fluvial channels (Allen, 1983; Friend, 1983; 205 

Miall, 1996). 206 

 This facies association was found in five outcrops (8, 9, 11, 12, 13) in the Alagoas 207 

sub-basin. These outcrops have the common characteristic of being located close to 208 

the Propriá Fault, which controls the majority of extension and source of sediment 209 



9  

supply at that time of the the syn-rift tectonic. In such a proximal domain, these thick 210 

fluvial successions were probably connected to a boarder alluvial fan, even if it was 211 

not be observed on the field. 212 

5.2. Distributary channel facies association 213 

5.2.1. Description 214 

 This facies association (Fig. 5) is up to 5.75 m thick, and dominantly composed of 215 

very fine to fine-grained sandstones with ripple cross-lamination (Sr), and, less 216 

commonly, horizontal lamination (Sh), low-angle cross-stratification (Sl), and planar 217 

cross-stratification (Sp). Bioclastic conglomerates, massive or with low-angle cross-218 

stratification (Gm, Gl), and, more rarely, massive matrix-supported conglomerate 219 

(Gmm) form the basal part of the channel. The base is usually erosive, overlying 220 

massive or laminated mudstones (Fm, Fl), generating incisions up to 1.6 m (Fig. 5). 221 

Basal conglomerates are thin (<40 cm) and laterally discontinuous (few meters). The 222 

bioclastic conglomerates shows fragments of bones and fish scales up to 3 cm, 223 

possibly of a lungfish, in addition to a tooth that potentially belonged to a terrestrial 224 

animal. These erosive conglomerates are superposed by sheet sandstone bodies 225 

(mostly Sr), with low dispersion of paleocurrents, extending laterally for tens to 226 

hundreds of meters. Like in braided distributary channel facies association, 227 

paleocurrent patterns of superposed sheet sandstones (Sr, Sh, Sl, Sp) show a 228 

direction of transport close or equal to the basal erosive conglomerate (Gl, Gm). Thin 229 

(<80 cm) greenish mudstones that extend laterally for tens of meters may be 230 

interbedded in the succession. Locally, the basal conglomerates are directly overlain 231 

by fine-grained, low-angle (Sl) and planar (Sp) cross-stratified sandstones (<60 cm 232 

thick). 233 

5.2.2. Interpretation 234 



10  

 The presence of sand bodies with unidirectional tractive structures, locally forming 235 

well-defined fining-upward cycles, and the occurrence of incisions at the base the 236 

sedimentary succession, suggest deposition in a fluvial channel. The dominance of 237 

very-fine-grained sand bodies, with lateral migration, interfingered with massive 238 

mudstones interpreted as overbank deposits, allowed the interpretation of a 239 

meandering distributary channel system for two section (section 6, 7). The vertical 240 

succession with prodelta deposits, the common presence of fish bone fragments in 241 

the erosive bioclastic conglomerates, and the predominance of very-fine to fine-242 

grained ripple cross-laminated bodies filling the channel (Sr), indicate that the 243 

meandering channel was occasionally directly connected with the distal part of the 244 

delta, under conditions of low energy with low sediment supply. 245 

5.3. Interdistributary bay facies association 246 

5.3.1. Description 247 

      This facies association (Fig. 5) has a variable thickness of 10 cm to 1.75 m, and 248 

is mostly composed of massive greenish to yellowish, rarely reddish mudstones 249 

(Fm), ripple cross-laminated (Fr), and, subordinately, weakly bioturbated mudstones 250 

(Fb). Within the horizon, millimeter to centimetric orange oxides nodules are often 251 

observed. The fine-grained deposits are laterally extensive for tens of meters, 252 

interlayered with meandering distributary channel deposits (Fig. 5), and generally 253 

overlying ripple cross-laminated sandstones (Sr) with an abrupt contact. 254 

5.3.2. Interpretation 255 

      The mud-dominated, the presence of oxides resulting from aerobic conditions, 256 

the laterally extensive nature of this facies association,  interlayering with deposits 257 

interpreted as distributary channel system, allow the interpretation of interdistributary 258 

bays. The fine-grained sediments were deposited abruptly onto channel sand bodies 259 

as a result of a break in the distributary channel during flood stage. The installation of 260 



11  

interdistributary bays as overbank sediments took place in a quiet-water environment 261 

with low sedimentation rates. 262 

5.4. Proximal delta front facies association 263 

5.4.1. Description 264 

      This facies association (Fig. 6) has a maximum thickness of 7 m and is mostly 265 

composed of medium-to fine-grained yellowish sandstones with cross-stratification 266 

(St), horizontal lamination (Sh), convoluted and deformed lamination (Sd), arranged 267 

in packages with thickness of decimeters to few meters. Less commonly, thinner low-268 

angle cross-stratified (Sl), ripple cross-laminated (Sr) and massive (Sm) sandstones 269 

occur. In addition, intraformational conglomerates (15-30 cm thick) are present along 270 

a scoured surface in the sand body succession. The conglomerates are massive, 271 

matrix-supported, bioclastic or intraclastic (mud clasts up to 2 cm) (Gm, Gmm). The 272 

sand bodies display a sheet geometry, commonly extending for tens to hundreds 273 

meters. Locally, matrix-supported conglomerates (Gd), with mud matrix and 274 

dispersed sandy blocks (up to 4.9 m) with syn-sedimentary deformation features, sit 275 

on a slip surface, forming slump deposits. This facies association is mostly overlain 276 

fine-grained prodelta deposits. 277 

5.4.2. Interpretation 278 

      The occurrence of thick, stacked sandy bodies with tractive structures, laterally 279 

extensive, locally forming well-defined coarsening-upward cycles, superimposed onto 280 

fine-grained prodelta deposits, point to deposition and progradation of a proximal 281 

delta front system. Due to fluctuations in fluvial discharge, coarsening-upward cycles 282 

and the thickness of sand bodies are not regular. The coarsest and better-sorted 283 

sand deposits, with mostly unidirectional tractive structures (St, Sp, Sl and Sh) were 284 

interpreted as river-dominated distributary-mouth bar deposits, formed by riverine 285 

inflow in a low-energy, lacustrine system, accompanied by significant slope break 286 



12  

and rapid flow deceleration. In river-dominated delta environments, high deposition 287 

rates may occur in a short period of time. Combined with the gravitational instability in 288 

this area, and the volume of accomodation, it is not uncommon to develop 289 

deformational fluidization structures, such as decimetric to metric flames structures 290 

and convoluted laminations (Gd, Sd), which represent large quantities of sediment 291 

transported from the mouth bar to deeper water (Battacharya, 2010) (Fig. 6). 292 

Internally, the rare presence of scoured erosive surfaces, laterally extensive 293 

interpreted as lag deposits of distributary channel, suggest episodic incursions of the 294 

channel and increasing progradation (regression) of the deltaic system.  295 

5.5. Distal delta front facies association 296 

5.5.1. Description 297 

      This facies association (Fig. 7), up to 5.5 m thick, consist mostly of very fine-to 298 

fine-grained sandstones, well sorted, with ripple cross-lamination (Sr), and, less 299 

commonly, massive (Sm), intercalated with heterolites (H, Hr) and greenish massive 300 

mudstones (Fm). The ripple cross-laminated sandstones are generally thicker (up to 301 

1.20 m thick) and present subcritical- to critical-climbing ripple lamination, arranged in 302 

stacked packages of few centimeters thick. The thickness of the massive sandstones 303 

is very heterogeneous (10 cm to 1.10 m thick). Heterolite successions (25 cm to 2 m 304 

thick) are characterized by centimeter-thick interlayers of sandstones and mudstones 305 

in variable proportions, and the presence or not of ripple cross-lamination (Hr) in very 306 

fine-grained sandstones. Massive greenish mudstones (Fm) are mostly siltstones, 307 

with local thin (millimeter-thick) interbeds of massive sandstones. The stratigraphic 308 

successions in this facies association are laterally extensive for tens to hundreds of 309 

meters. 310 

5.5.2. Interpretation 311 



13  

 This facies association is interpreted as distal delta front based on the 312 

predominance of very fine-grained sandstones with unidirectional tractive structures, 313 

overlying massive mudstones of prodelta deposited from suspension, forming 314 

progradational cycles. This succession reflects an increase in sediment supply at the 315 

mouth bar, progressively filling the accommodation space by sand discharges. 316 

Internally, the metric sandstone/siltstone alternations reflect smaller scales 317 

(seasonal?) changes in river discharge. Despite the dominance of fine-grained 318 

lithologies, the sandstone/mudstone ratio is much higher than in the prodelta 319 

deposits, which was the main criterion to differentiate distal delta front and prodelta 320 

successions in the studied sections. 321 

5.6. Prodelta facies association 322 

5.6.1. Description 323 

 This facies association (Fig. 7) has a variable thickness of 1 m to 2.5 m, and is 324 

laterally extensive for tens to hundreds of meters. These deposits consists of 325 

dominantly decimetric to metric, gray to greenish mudstones that alternate between 326 

massive (Fm) (20 cm to 2.50 m thick) and laminated mudstones (Fl) (80 cm to 2.25 m 327 

thick). They are interbedded with cross-laminated sandstones to mudstones (Sr, Fr), 328 

cross-laminated heterolites (Hr) and, subordinately, weakly bioturbated mudstones 329 

(Fb) (Fig. 7), and thin (<25 cm), very fine-grained sandstone layers (Sm, Sh and Sd).  330 

5.6.2. Interpretation 331 

 The predominance of fine-grained deposits point to deposition in low-energy 332 

environment. This facies association is overlain by delta front and distributary 333 

channel successions (Fig. 5, 7). The limited bioturbation in mudstones is interpreted 334 

as gravitational settling in a dysoxic, deep water body. The thin sandstones 335 

intercalated with mudstones represent episodic increases in discharge from the 336 



14  

feeder river that allowed transport and deposition of sand bodies to distal parts of the 337 

deltaic system (prodelta). 338 

5.7. Lacustrine facies association 339 

5.7.1. Description 340 

 This facies association (Fig. 8) is represented in only one outcrop (6). It consists 341 

of homogeneous, gray to greenish laminated mudstones (Fl), 2.75 m thick. These 342 

deposits show weak bioturbation, with horizontal and vertical burrows. Differently 343 

from the prodelta deposits, this succession is devoid of thin interbedded sandstones. 344 

5.7.2. Interpretation 345 

 The deposition of laminated mudstones (Fl) indicate a quiet and relatively deep-346 

water body, with low sedimentation rates, and a sedimentation by gravitational 347 

settling of suspended particles (Miall, 1977). The absence of roots and desiccation 348 

features suggests a perennial lake. The dominance of muddy sediments, the 349 

absence of intercalated very fine-grained sandstones and features indicative of 350 

subaerial exposure, and the presence of bioturbation suggest deposition in very low 351 

energy conditions in a lacustrine environment (Battacharya, 2006).  The reduced 352 

thickness and lateral extension (tens of meters) of these deposits, and the absence 353 

of organic mudstones point to a shallow, small lake. 354 

6. Paleoenvironmental reconstructions 355 

6.1. Fundamental concepts 356 

  Recent studies proposed a model for the stratigraphic record in rift basins, 357 

providing a better understanding of the relationship between sediment supply and 358 

accommodation in stratigraphic sequences, and of basin infilling  (Catuneanu, 2006). 359 

In deltaic-lacustrine successions developed in rift systems, accommodation is 360 

created, or lost, as a result of tectonic activity. Subsidence along the border normal 361 



15  

fault is the major control, closely linked with climatic controls and eustatic base-level 362 

fluctuations of the lake. The interactions of these controls result in different 363 

depositional trends (progradation or retrogradation), intimately linked with stratal 364 

stacking patterns that characterize changes in accommodation space and sediment 365 

supply ratio (A/S) (Weimer and Posamentier, 1993; Emery and Myers, 1996; 366 

Posamentier and Allen, 1999; Catuneanu, 2002, 2006; Martins-Neto & Catuneanu, 367 

2009). In recent years, research has been carried out to understand the dominance 368 

of axial over transversal sediment supply in rift basins (Fordham et al, 2010; 369 

Weissman et al., 2010). Using data from the semi-arid northern Basin and Range, 370 

USA, and data from others authors, Fordham et al. (2010) concluded that transversal 371 

systems from the border faults are dominant and finer grained during early syn-rift 372 

phases, gradually turning into an axial rift filling through time, as the intensity of the 373 

syn-rift tectonic activity decreases. This suggests that a larger role for transversal 374 

drainage should be considered in comparison with axial drainage, which is generally 375 

taken as the main filling system (Schlishe, 1991; Prosser, 1993; Lambiase & Morley, 376 

1999) in the onset of the rift phase. 377 

6.2. Regional paleo-physiographic reconstructions 378 

     The study area was divided into several sub-areas, representing various structural 379 

compartments (graben/half-graben) (Fig. 9) delimited by extensive border faults, 380 

components of an extension represented by graben and half-grabens associated with 381 

regional drainage systems and depocenters. 382 

6.2.1. Compartment A 383 

 This area (Fig. 10) include two outcrops (1, 2), 4.2 km away from each other along 384 

a NW to SE direction. 385 

 Located at the edge of the Propriá fault, oriented NE-SW and dipping to the SE, 386 

Section 1 is 5.4 m thick, and dominantly composed of fine-grained deformed 387 



16  

sandstones (Sd) and ripple cross-laminated sandstones (Sr), interpreted as proximal 388 

delta front deposits. In the middle part of this succession, massive matrix-supported 389 

conglomerates (Gmm), associated with thin deformed sandstones, heterolites with 390 

ripple cross-lamination (Hr), and fine bioturbated mudstones (Fb), were interpreted as 391 

delta plain deposits. Thin, scoured erosive surfaces within the sand bodies were 392 

interpreted as lag deposits of distributary channels. Paleocurrent measurements in 393 

ripple cross-lamination shows paleoflow towards the southeast. 394 

 Section 2, 8.4 m thick, is located at the edge of a NE-SW oriented normal fault 395 

created during the propagation of the Propriá fault. The succession comprises 396 

massive prodelta mudstones (Fm) at the base,  overlain by laterally extensive, fine-397 

grained sand bodies (Sh, St, Sd) interpreted as proximal delta front deposits, capped 398 

by fine, rippled sandstones (Sr) deposited in distal delta fronts. Greenish siltstones 399 

(Fm) interlayed with thin, massive sandstones (Sm) formed distal delta front-prodelta 400 

deposits and the top of the succession. Paleocurrent directions display paleoflow 401 

towards the southeast. 402 

      The vertical succession and paleocurrent directions suggest deposition in 403 

proximal to distal delta front, in a transversal delta sourced from the two normal 404 

border faults (Fig. 10B). Thus at this location axial contribution from the associated 405 

normal release fault (Destro, 1995; Cruz, L.R, 2008), oriented NNW-SSE, seems to 406 

be absent. Proximal deltaic sand bodies progressively filled the accommodation 407 

space by transversal catchment. In section 1, repetitive incursions of erosive 408 

distributary channel invoke a relatively proximal domain and the frequent 409 

establishment and sedimentation in delta plain environment, in a period of base-level 410 

fall with high sediment supply relative to accommodation. In section 2, the presence 411 

of fine-grained prodelta deposits implies a period of high accommodation and low 412 

sediment supply (Martins-Neto & Catuneanu, 2009).  413 



17  

6.2.2. Compartment B 414 

 This area (Fig. 12) is represented by three outcrops (3, 4, 5), separated 1.85 km 415 

along a SW to NE direction. They are located in a syn-rift graben linked to the main 416 

rift extension, delimited by two parallel normal faults oriented SW-NE. 417 

 Section 3, 20.3 m thick, shows mostly medium-grained sandstones (Sh, St, Sp, 418 

Sd) deposited in a proximal delta front, associated with ripple cross-laminated 419 

sandstones (Sr), cross-laminated heterolites (Hr), and massive mudstones (Fm) 420 

accumulated in a distal delta front. The base of the succession is represented by an 421 

erosive distributary channel (Gmm) overlying facies of distal delta front, and point to a 422 

drop in base (lake) level with an axial sedimentary contribution in the area.      423 

 Section 4, 23 m thick, is characterized by thick, coarse- to fine-grained 424 

sandstones (Sh, Sd, St, Sl), interpreted as proximal delta front deposits (mouth bar), 425 

intimately associated with basal deposits of fluvial channel (Gt). The reddish 426 

coloration of fine deposits (Fm) at the top of the fluvial succession (Sm), and above 427 

delta front (Sh) is probably due to long-term subaerial exposure with chemical 428 

precipitation, and the probable identification of root marks (Fig. 11) represent the 429 

installation of a paleosol under interdistributary bay environment (arid conditions?). 430 

The upper part is mainly represented by fluidized sandstones (Sd) deposited in 431 

proximal delta front mouth bars, which covers a surface of non-deposition (paleosol), 432 

and characterized base level rise with renewable creation of accommodation, 433 

instantly filled by proximal delta bars. The entire succession represents a relatively 434 

proximal zone, marking the interconnection of a river channel (Gt) with deltaic 435 

proximal bars (Gt, Sh, Sd) filling a probably shallow lake (paleosols) during a rapid 436 

phase of lake level rise. The paleosols (10-30 cm) mark a drop of the lake level, 437 

leaving the region exposed to aerial erosion, accompanied by the development of 438 



18  

vegetation (root marks) in more humid periods (precipitations) with lateral migration 439 

of the deltaic system (distributary channel). 440 

 Section 5, 250 m away from Section 4, consists mostly of fine- to very-fine-441 

grained delta front sandstones (Sr, St, Sm, Sh), interlayered with gray to greenish 442 

massive prodeltaic mudstones. This coarsening-upward succession shows a typical 443 

delta progradation with the transition of distal facies (prodelta) which grade into 444 

proximal facies (mouth bar at the top).  445 

 Delta plain facies are only present in Section 3 and 4, where distributary channel 446 

facies overlie delta front facies. Paleocurrent measurements in sections 3 and 5 447 

display a fairly large dispersion. In section 3, paleocurrent directions in deltaic 448 

sandstones indicate paleoflow to the southeast, while directions measured in trough 449 

cross-bedded (St) and ripple cross-laminated (Sr) sandstones of distributary channel 450 

indicate paleoflow towards the northeast. In Section 5, paleocurrent directions point 451 

to two major source of sedimentary input, from the east and from the west. 452 

      The analysis of vertical successions and paleocurrents indicate that 453 

sedimentation occurred dominantly in proximal delta front, filling the depression as a 454 

dominantly axial delta, with sedimentary contribution from the two normal fault 455 

boundaries, principally from the NW fault, which is dipping in the same direction that 456 

principal rift extension (Fig. 12B). 457 

6.2.3. Compartment C 458 

      This area (Fig. 13) is represented by two outcrops (6, 7), 460 m away from each 459 

other from NW to SE. Based on the bedding orientation and horizontal distance 460 

between the two sections, estimated stratigraphic hiatus between 6 and 7 is 119 m, 461 

with Section 7 overlying Section 6. They are located near a normal fault dipping to 462 

the southeast. These sections are the most complete sections in the study area. The 463 

Section 6 is 29.8 thick, and Section 7 is represented by the description of two 464 



19  

stratigraphic columnar profiles (24.5 m and 11.3 m), laterally separated by several 465 

un-covered meters, correlated with the identification of a correlative conformity 466 

represented by cross-laminated sandstones (Sr) and thick prodeltaic deposits (Fm) 467 

that exhibit 60 meters of lateral extension. 468 

 Facies analysis allowed to identify retrogradacional (lacustrine transgression)/ 469 

progradational (coarsening-upward delta progradation) cycles controlled by 470 

accommodation space creation and sediment supply (A/S ratio), variations in base-471 

level of lake, based on the application of the sequence stratigraphy model for rift of 472 

Martins-Neto & Catuneanu (2009) in higher-frequency sequences. The top of each 473 

sequence is usually marked by proximal delta facies (end of the progradation). The 474 

transition of each cycles was based on the identification of maximum flooding 475 

surfaces (MFS), which mark the climax of retrogradational cycle, generally identified 476 

in dark-grey mudstones deposited in prodelta or lake. Based on the thickness of 477 

sequences, the identified stratigraphic cycles are 4
th

 or 5
th

 order, possibly strongly 478 

controlled by climate, related with Milankovitch cycles (eccentricity and obliquity) 479 

during the Lower Cretaceous (Berger et al.; 1992; Santos, 2005; Borba, 2009).  480 

 Section 6 began with a retrogradational stacking pattern at the base 11 meters 481 

thick, composed of distal delta front deposits that gradually evolving into lacustrine 482 

mudstones (MFS). Lacustrine deposits are followed by a coarsening-upward 483 

succession represented by a delta progradation that end with delta front facies (LS 484 

1). Sequence 2 begins with a new retrogradation stacking pattern, with the deposition 485 

of homogeneous mudstones of prodelta (Fm), followed and by a new progradational 486 

trend represented by the deposition of fine sediments alternating between distal bars 487 

of delta front with fine mudstones. The upper part of the cycle is composed by fluvial 488 

deposits interpreted as meandering distributary channels that covered with erosive 489 

base fine deposits of distal delta front (Sr) and end the delta progradation (LS 2). This 490 



20  

points to a significant decrease in accommodation space related to increasing 491 

sediment supply (A <S). Paleocurrent measurements obtained in delta bars indicate 492 

a paleoflow towards the south. 493 

 Section 7 display the same stratigraphic pattern that Section 6, except that 494 

lacustrine facies are not present and proximal environments (meandering distributary 495 

channels) are better represented. However, it is important to realize that the 496 

sequences in Section 7 are not equivalent to those in Section 6, since Section 7 is 497 

about 119 m stratigraphically above Section 6. Despite the stratigraphic hiatus 498 

between the two sections, sequence denomination will be sequentially numbered. 499 

The section begins with the top of a probably progradational succession (L3), 500 

represented by distributary channel deposits (LS 3). The beginning of sequence 4 501 

marks a new retrogradational trend, relatively long and less pronounced (delta front 502 

deposits interlayered between prodelta mudstones), covered by delta progradation, 503 

rapidly dominated by regressive deposits of meandering distributary channel (Gl, Sr), 504 

themselves covered by fine greenish clays of interdistributary bay (LS 4). The new 505 

retrogradational cycle is represented by proximal mouth-bars quickly evolving into 506 

lacustrine deposits. The following progradational phase completes the deposition of 507 

sequence 5 with the accumulation of distal delta front and prodelta deposits, covered 508 

by an erosive distributary channel. The last sequence (6) begins and marks an 509 

important lake deepening, initially represented by the deposition of mouth-bars, 510 

progressively evolving to prodelta. The prograding phase that follows is represented 511 

by erosive distributary meandering channel (Sr) flowing to the southeast (subsection 512 

1). In subsection 2, the latter progradacional trend begins with thick matrix-supported 513 

conglomerates (Gd) showing sedimentary structures of fluidization (decimetric to 514 

metric), and probably connected with distributary channel of portion 1. The 515 

conglomerates are based on a sliding surface with a high angle of inclination and 516 



21  

represent an important volume of sediments transported and deposited by 517 

gravitational instability in the deepest parts (lake, prodelta). Covering this thick and 518 

erosive package, the deltaic progradation continues with thick and large scale 519 

proximal bars of delta front with paleoflow towards the east. 520 

 The stratigraphic record and paleoflow directions in these sections show that the 521 

region was dominated by a transversal delta system sourced at the normal border 522 

fault, prograding towards southeast-est. At the end of coarsening-upward cycles, the 523 

establishment of meandering distributary channels indicates periods of low 524 

accommodation relative to sediment supply, with base-level falls resulting in a forced 525 

regression, incision and incursion of proximal channels in deeper parts of the deltaic 526 

system (prodelta). At the opposite, the retrogradational cycle shows generally a 527 

fining-upward succession of fine deposits indicating renewal accommodation space 528 

with low sediment supply and base-level rise. This period is characterized by a 529 

retreat of proximal deltaic environments towards border fault (proximal flexural 530 

margin). These higher-frequency cycles were probably strongly influenced by climatic 531 

effects and composed low-order level sequence (3
th 

order), largely controlled by 532 

tectonic activity (pulse and fault reactivation). 533 

6.2.4. Compartment D 534 

      This area (Fig. 14) is represented by two outcrops (8, 9), 790 m away from each 535 

other along a NW to SE direction. Section 9 overlies section 8 with an estimated 536 

stratigraphic hiatus of 333 m between them. These sections are bordered by two 537 

major normal faults intimately linked with the main rift extension, with the normal 538 

Propriá fault parallel the rift strike, and the second normal NW-SE oriented fault, 539 

dipping to the southwest, perpendicular to the Propriá fault strike, apparently a 540 

release fault to accommodate the extension. 541 



22  

 Section 8, 7 m thick, is mostly composed of medium- to fine-grained cross-bedded 542 

sandstones (St) deposited in a proximal delta front, overlain with erosive contact by 543 

braided distributary channel deposits (Gmm, St). Paleocurrent directions indicate 544 

paleoflow towards the east. 545 

 Section 9, 18.7 m thick, is characterized by trough cross-bedded conglomerates 546 

(Gt) with sub-angular quartz clasts up to 5 cm in diameter, associated with coarse- to 547 

medium-grained cross-bedded sandstones (St), and interpreted as proximal braided 548 

distributary channels. The base of the section (Gt, St) displays paleoflow towards the 549 

east, and the presence of the red ferruginous crust at the top suggest subaerial 550 

exposure. It is separated from the top section by 13 m of un-exposed succession. 551 

The top of the succession is characterized by the presence of reactivation surfaces 552 

marked by sub-angular quartz granules at the base of each cross-stratified set. 553 

Paleocurrent directions with low dispersion indicate paleoflow towards the west-554 

southwest. 555 

      Because of the large stratigraphic hiatus between sections 8 and 9, it is difficult to 556 

fully understand the stratigraphic record in this area. Nonetheless, it appears that this 557 

region was primarily filled by a transversal delta system sourced at the Propriá fault 558 

(section 8). Later on, the region was controlled by a combination of two transversal 559 

deltas (Section 9). Paleocurrent directions initially indicate that transversal input by 560 

proximal distributary channels flowing from the Propriá fault into the basin, followed 561 

by transversal contribution from the normal release fault.  The proximal deltaic 562 

succession recorded in compartment D was probably deposited during late stages of 563 

extension, based on the tectonic activity along the normal release fault (which serves 564 

to accommodate extension), the occurrence of thick amalgamated sandstones of 565 

braided distributary channels, and the large stratigraphic hiatus with similar proximal 566 

depositional environment. 567 



23  

6.2.5. Compartment E 568 

 This area (Fig. 15) includes only one outcrop (10), 18.7 m thick, located in a syn-569 

rift half graben delimited by two parallel SW-NE oriented normal faults . This section 570 

is mostly composed of fine- to very fine-grained sandstones with ripple cross-571 

laminated (Sr), trough cross-bedded (St), and, subordinately, low-angle cross-572 

bedding (Sl), and massive siltstones. The base comprises stacked ripple cross-573 

laminated beds (Sr) deposited in a proximal to distal delta front environment. 574 

Paleocurrent directions show a low dispersion, with paleoflow towards the northeast. 575 

Sediment dispersal orientation indicates an axial input for the formation of the delta. 576 

The top of the succession is erosive onto fine-grained distal delta front deposits, 577 

representing deposition in meandering distributary channels with paleoflow towards 578 

southeast. This paleocurrent direction showS transversal sediment input and 579 

contribution from the border fault.  580 

6.2.6. Compartment F 581 

 This area (Fig. 16) comprise two outcrops (11, 12), 450 m away from each other 582 

along a NE to SW direction. The estimated stratigraphic hiatus between 11 and 12 is 583 

116 m, with section 12 overlying section 11. The sections are located near the 584 

Propriá fault (flexural margin), which is dipping to the south in this area. Section 11, 585 

7.4 m thick, displays trough cross-stratified sandy conglomerate (Gt) at the base, 586 

overlain by stacked sets of cross-stratified sandstones (St) with reactivation surfaces. 587 

This association was interpreted as braided distributary channels. Section 12, 8.7 m 588 

thick, consist mostly of medium- to fine-grained cross-stratified sandstones (St) 589 

deposited in proximal delta fronts, overlain by cross-stratified sandstones (St) 590 

interpreted as braided distributary channel deposits. The transition is marked by 591 

trough cross-bedded conglomerates (Gt) onto a scoured erosive surface that 592 



24  

represents channel lag deposits. In both sections, paleocurrent analysis indicates 593 

paleoflow dominantly towards the east-southeast. 594 

 Paleoflow direction, and the dominance of braided distributary channel deposits 595 

overlying proximal delta front deposits point to delta progradation fed by axial input. 596 

Since these sections are located near the normal border fault, this fluvio-deltaic 597 

system is probably alimented by transversal alluvial fans (Gawthorpe & Leeder, 598 

2000).  At the base of section 12, the paleocurrent measurements obtained on 599 

proximal delta bars (St) exhibit a transverse paleoflow towards southwest, while 600 

following directions on sets suggests an axial contribution. 601 

6.2.7. Compartment G 602 

      This area (Fig. 17) is composed by only one outcrop (13), 12.8 m thick, located 603 

near a NE-SW elongated graben system. The eastern Penedo fault (Fig. 17), dipping 604 

to the northwest, controls infilling of this compartment in the study area. The section 605 

consists of fine-grained sand bodies deposited in proximal delta fronts, largely 606 

dominated by laterally extensive, thick fluidized and trough cross-stratified 607 

sandstones (Sd, St). The presence of an erosive contact mid-section with massive, 608 

matrix-supported conglomerate (Gmm) is interpreted as lag deposits of prograding 609 

braided distributary channels. Paleocurrent measurements indicate paleoflow 610 

towards to the east-southeast and that delta outbuild is governed by an axial 611 

discharge within the graben compartment. 612 

 The deposition of thick fluidized, trough cross-stratified sand bodies represent the 613 

development of a relatively large (hundreds of meters to kilometer due to 614 

compartment size and high lateral extension) and well-developed (thick) delta front 615 

system. This points out that the hydraulic regime in the upstream segment of the river 616 

sourced had to be sufficiently powerful to transport this sedimentary load in proximal 617 

parts of the lake (proximal bars). It is probably that the axial drainage system was 618 



25  

connected upstream with relatively deep river channels (meandering?), frequently 619 

alimented in fine sand sediments, already well rounded by a long transport prior. 620 

Towards the southwest, this prograding delta was possibly connected with more 621 

distal delta environments (distal delta front, prodelta), with some transversal 622 

contributions from the normal fault dipping to the southeast. 623 

7. Conclusions 624 

1.  The Barra de Itiúba Formation, analyzed in thirteen sections, comprises of 625 

deltaic and lacustrine deposits accumulated in syn-rift grabens and half-grabens 626 

linked to the main extensional phase along the Propriá border fault. 627 

2.  Facies analysis allowed the recognition of 17 facies, grouped into seven facies 628 

associations: (1) Braided distributary channel; (2) (Meandering) Distributary channel; 629 

(3) Interdistributary bay; (4) Proximal delta front; (5) Distal delta front; (6) Prodelta; 630 

and (7) Lacustrine. 631 

3.  Identifying retrogradacional/progradational cycles according to rift sequence 632 

sratigraphy model of Martins-Neto & Catuneanu (2009), the description of two 633 

stratigraphic sections (6, 7) allowed the identification of probably 4
th

-order  634 

stratigraphic sequences, only represented in this study by retrogradacional 635 

successions (bounded by maximum flooding surface at the top) and delta 636 

progradations. The first show a fining-upwards succession evolving to distal facies of 637 

prodelta and lacustrine (Fm, Fl, Fb), characterizing lake base-level rise with low 638 

sediment supply relative to accommodation. Progradational trends are usually 639 

represented by a thick coarsening-upward  delta progradation, showing vertical 640 

passage of distal to proximal environments, largely representing by proximal mouth-641 

bars (St) and fluidized sandstones of delta front (Sd), covered by erosive distributary 642 

channels (meandering and braided), which fills the lake accommodation. In the same 643 



26  

way as the description of two well profiles of Sergipe-Alagoas basin (identification of 644 

3
th

-order sequences of Barra de Itiúba Formation), in an attempt to better interpret 645 

these retrogradational/progradational cycles characterizing lake systems tract in low-646 

order level sequences (largely controlled by tectonic pulses), the sequential 647 

description of these two sections adapted from the model of Martins-Neto & 648 

Catuneaunu (2009) will be part of other research paper. 649 

4. Reconstruction of the deltaic system physiography was not possible for the entire 650 

study area due to the scarce occurrence and thins outcrops and the high degree of 651 

basin compartmentation into grabens and half-grabens. However, integration 652 

between facies and paleocurrent analyses into the structural context by 653 

individualization of grabens/half-grabens (compartments) provided a better idea of 654 

the axial versus transversal contribution in rift settings. Nevertheless, these results 655 

should be interpreted with caution, as well as the fact that these undated outcrops 656 

(absence of ostracodes) cannot be quite representative comparing with the thickness 657 

of the sedimentary record of the Barra de Itiúba Formation studied in well sections 658 

(181 m in Sergipe portion, and 655 m in Alagoas depocenters); represented by 659 

several 3
th

-order sequences. 660 

5. Paleocurrent analysis shows that, depending of the sub-areas considered, 661 

sedimentary input changes from transversal to axial sources. Most studied sections 662 

were located near the normal border faults, where sediment input generally derives 663 

from alluvial fans developed along the border fault, transversal to the graben 664 

structures. The deposition of proximal, coarse-grained facies (conglomerates and 665 

coarse to fine-grained sandstones) of distributary channel and proximal delta front 666 

were substantially dominated by transversal drainage. Even if it is not obvious, this is 667 

in agreement with Fordham et al (2010) and Weissmann et al (2010) suggestion that 668 

transversal drainage development should be taken more into account to explain 669 



27  

stratigraphic architecture of syn-rift deposits.  Axial drainage was more significant in 670 

wider compartments, particularly in section 13, by thick fluidized sand bodies, part of 671 

axial proximal delta front, already well established along the normal fault of Penedo. 672

Facies Description Interpretation 
 
Gmm 

Massive, matrix-supported conglomerates, poorly sorted; 
sub-angular grain; dominant quartz granules (subordinate 
feldspar and rock fragments); incipient gradation and 
erosive base; 10 to 40 cm thick beds. 

Plastic debris flow (high-strength, viscous) 
(Miall, 1996). 

Gm Bioclastic, clast-supported conglomerates; fine sandstone 
matrix; bone fragments (<2 cm) and mud intraclasts (<2 
cm); 10 to 20 cm thick beds. 

Bedload deposition as diffuse gravel layers 
(Hein & Walker, 1997) or lags deposits by high-
magnitude flood flows (Miall, 1977; Nemec and 
Postma, 1993). 
 

Gd Matrix-supported conglomerates with deformed sandstone 
blocks (up to 4.9 m); rafts of heterolites and highly-deformed 
muds; 2 m thick bed. 

Deformation of unconsolidated sediments by 
gravitational instability (Anketell et al., 1970; 
Selker, 1993; Moretti et al., 1999). 

Gi Intraformational, clast-supported conglomerates; very fine 
sandstone matrix; mud intraclasts (<2cm); 40 thick bed. 

Fragmented mud cracks incorporated to 
tractive flows (Glennie, 1970); or collapsed 
banks by hyperconcentrated flows (Coleman, 
1969). 

Gl Bioclastic, matrix to clast-supported conglomerates with 
low-angle cross-stratification; bone fragments (<3cm) and 
mud intraclasts (<2cm); 15 to 50 cm thick beds. 

Humback or washed-out dunes (transitional 
flow regime) (Miall, 1996).  

Gt Clast-supported conglomerates with trough cross-
stratification; sub-angular grains; dominant quartz and 
feldspar granules (rare rock fragments); 10 cm to 1 m thick 
sets. 

3D gravel dunes (Rust, 1978; Todd, 1996). 

Sh Fine- to medium-grained sandstones with horizontal 
lamination; moderately- to well-sorted; 15 cm to 3 m thick 
beds. 

Planar-bedded deposits originated via upper 
flow regime (Miall, 1977; Best and Bridge, 
1992; Marshall, 2000). 

St Fine- to coarse-grained sandstones with trough cross-
stratification; poorly- to well-sorted; sub-angular grains; 
Dominant quartz granules; locally erosive base; 25 cm to 
1.20 m thick sets. 

3D subaqueous sandy dunes deposited via 
lower flow regime (Harms et al.; 1982; Miall, 
1996; Collinson et al.; 2006). 

Sp Fine- to medium-grained sandstones with planar cross-
stratification; moderately- to well-sorted; 40 cm to 1.20m 
thick sets. 

2D subaqueous sandy dunes deposited via 
lower flow regime (Harms et al.; 1982; Miall, 
1996; Collinson et al.; 2006). 

Sr Very fine- to medium-grained sandstones with ripple cross-
lamination (subcritical to critical climbing angle); 
moderately- to well-sorted; centimeter-thick sets forming up 
to 4.20 m thick cosets.  

Small-scale ripple migration in unidirectional 
lower flow regime (Allen, 1963; Miall, 1996). 

Sd Fine- to medium-grained sandstones with convoluted 
lamination and flame structure; moderately- to well-sorted; 
relicts of laminated mud common; 25 cm to 4 m thick beds. 

Deposits deformed by fluidization.  

Sm Fine-to medium-grained, massive sandstones; locally sub-
angular quartz granules; 20 cm to 2 m thick beds. 

Deposition of hyperconcentrated flows, 
fluidization or intensive bioturbation (Todd, 
1989; Miall, 1978, 1996). 

H Heterolites with linsen bedding formed by intercalation of 
massive siltstones and very fine-grained sandstones; 10 cm 
to 1 m thick beds. 

Variation of energy levels, with gravitational 
settling from suspension alternating with 
deposition from hyperconcentrated flows 
(Miall, 1996). 

Hr Heterolites with linsen bedding and ripple cross-lamination 
(subcritical climbing angle) formed by intercalation of 
massive silt-mudstones and very fine- to fine-grained 
sandstones; 20 to 2.5 m thick beds. 

Variation of energy levels, with gravitational 
settling from suspension, alternating with 
deposition from ripple migration under 
unidirectional lower flow regime. 

Fr Siltstones- to very fine-grained sandstones with ripple cross-
lamination (critical climbing angle); moderately- to well-
sorted; 20 cm to 40 cm thick beds.  

Low-energy tractive currents (Miall, 1977). 

Fl Mudstones to siltstones with horizontal lamination; 
yellowish to gray; 15 cm to 2.7 m thick beds. 

Suspension settling.  
Zero flow velocity (Rogers & Astin, 1991). 

Fm Massive mudstones; greenish to gray, rarely reddish to 
yellowish; 15 cm to 2.5 m thick beds. 
May contain fossil root traces. 

Suspension settling.  
Zero flow velocity (Miall, 1977). 
Locally paleosol development (Retallack, 2001)

A new approach in high-resolution sequence stratigraphy of early rift deposits, 1 

Barra de Itiúba Formation, Sergipe-Alagoas basin, northeastern Brazil. 2

Simon Courivaud

, Karin Goldberg
