UFRGS, Instituto de Geosciências, Departamento de Estratigrafia, Bento Golçalves n. 9500, predio 5 

43137, Agronomia,  Porto Alegre, RS, Brazil. 6 

b 
Kansas State University, Department of Geology, 207 Thompson Hall, Manhattan, KS, 66506, USA. 7 

A B S T R A C T 8 

The Barra de Itiúba Formation (Hauterivian-Barremian) records the deposition in 9 

deltaic and lacustrine environments accumulated in the early syn-rift stage of the 10 

Sergipe-Alagoas Basin, northeastern Brazil. Detailed facies description in two wells 11 

and thirteen outcrops allowed the identification of 22 lithofacies, grouped in seven 12 

facies associations that characterize delta plain, delta front, prodelta, and lacustrine 13 

environments. Following the model of Martins-Neto & Catuneanu (2009, in press), 14 

detailed sequence stratigraphic studies carried out in the wells led to the definition of 15 

seven 3
th

 order stratigraphic sequences with depositional trends that reflect variation 16 

in the rate of creation/destruction of accommodation space and sediment supply (A/S 17 

ratio). Depositional sequences in the study area are composed of a: (1) Underfilled 18 

systems tract (UST), characterized by short stage of rapid accommodation 19 

(underfilled phase), mostly comprising lacustrine and prodelta facies associations; (2) 20 

Filled systems tract (FST), reflecting a long progradational trend (filled phase) during 21 

the tectonic quiescence, and mainly represented by distal to proximal delta front 22 

facies associations; and 3) Overfilled systems tract (OST), which characterize the 23 

overfilled phase that completes the sequence, formed by proximal distributary 24 

channel, crevasse splay and interdistributary bay facies associations. During the 25 

deposition of the Barra de Itiúba Formation, sedimentologic and stratigraphic 26 

evidence indicates that tectonic subsidence played a stronger role in the Alagoas 27 



2  

portion, during the syn-rift extension (second major tectonic pulse) of the Sergipe-28 

Alagoas basin.  29 

Keywords: Lower Cretaceous; Sergipe Alagoas-Basin; Sequence stratigraphy; 30 

lacustrine delta; syn-rift deposits. 31 

1.  Introduction 32 

      Sequence stratigraphy is based on the identification of different depositional 33 

trends (degradation, aggradation, progradation, retrogradation), intimately linked with 34 

changes in accommodation space and sediment supply, and resulting in different 35 

stratal stacking patterns that define transgressive, highstand, and lowstand systems 36 

tracts (Weimer and Posamentier, 1993; Emery and Myers, 1996; Posamentier and 37 

Allen, 1999; Catuneanu, 2002, 2006; Martins-Neto & Catuneanu, 2009, in press). In 38 

the last 30 years, many authors have attempted to use the sequence stratigraphic 39 

model, defined for passive margins, to provide a better understanding of the 40 

evolution and sedimentary filling in different types of basins, including rift basins 41 

(Posamentier and Vail, 1988; Posamentier et al., 1988; Posamentier and Allen, 42 

1999). In passive margin system, the stratigraphic framework and sedimentary filling 43 

are largely controlled by cyclic sea level fluctuations (rise or fall) in a context of long 44 

thermal subsidence, the opposite of what occurs in rift systems, which are 45 

characterized by strong mechanical subsidence that controls a dominantly 46 

continental sedimentation. 47 

 Following this fundamental difference, Martins-Neto & Catuneanu (2009, in press) 48 

proposed a sequence stratigraphic model for rift systems. This one include tectonic 49 

activity as main factor and allows to better characterize the sedimentary record of the 50 

entire rift Supersequence (1st order) through the identification of sequences in 51 

different levels of hierarchy (second and third order). In that context, even if climatic 52 

controls operate as an important factor on the stratigraphic record (high-frequency 53 



3  

sequences) an ideal sequence begins with a short stage of rapid accommodation 54 

(underfilled phase) linked to a pulse of extension along the border fault, forming a 55 

rapid and short retrogradacional trend. This deepening phase with low sedimentary 56 

discharge (A>S) is immediately followed by a long progradational trend (filled phase) 57 

during the tectonic quiescence when sediment supply consumes the available 58 

accommodation space created by during fault reactivation. In the latter stage, the 59 

basin can be fully filled, marking the moment when the basin enters in “overfilled” 60 

phase” mostly characterized by an erosive sedimentation of fluvial and proximal 61 

deposits. 62 

 The purpose of this paper is to apply and adapt the model proposed by Martins-63 

Neto & Catuneanu (2009, in press) to the deltaic-lacustrine Barra de Itiúba Formation 64 

(Hauterivian-Berremian), deposited in the Sergipe Alagoas Basin, northeastern 65 

Brazil, proposing a new sequence stratigraphic interpretation of the rift deposits. The 66 

goals are: (1) to identify facies and facies associations, representing specific 67 

depositional environments; (2) to identify key stratigraphic surfaces (flooding 68 

surfaces, maximum flooding surface, and erosive surfaces) to identify systems tracts 69 

and depositional sequences; and (3) to understand the tectono-stratigraphic 70 

evolution and discuss the main controls of the succession. 71 

2.  Geological setting 72 

      The Sergipe-Alagoas Basin, located on the Brazilian eastern margin (Fig. 1A), 73 

covers an onshore area of 13,000 km² of sediments and an offshore portion of 74 

32,760 km² (Mohriak, 2003). This basin was formed as a result from the evolution of 75 

an asymmetric rift elongated in NNE/SSW directions and separated in the south from 76 

the Jacuípe Basin by the Vaza-Barris fault system, and in the north from the 77 

Parnaíba-Pernambuco Basin by the Maragogi High (Feijó, 1994; Campos Neto et al., 78 

2007). Structurally, this basin consists of a southeastward-dipping half-graben 79 



4  

(Souza-Lima, 2002). Feijó (1994) separated the basin in two parts: the Sergipe and 80 

the Alagoas Basins, structurally separated by the Japoatã-Penedo High (Fig. 1A). 81 

However, according to Campos Neto et al., 2007, this structural complex is located in 82 

the onshore portion only and does not extend to the Charneira lower block, leaving 83 

doubts about the basin sub-division. In the outcrop area, extension was mostly 84 

controlled by the border normal fault, called Propriá Fault, associated with other 85 

NE/SW-oriented normal faults, and common NW/SE-oriented normal release faults, 86 

forming complex graben and half-graben systems (Destro, 1995). Due to the high 87 

dispersion on direction and orientation of normal faults, the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin 88 

shows a complex tectonic history. The basin can be subdivided into blocks (or 89 

tectonic compartments) limited by large normal faults (Fig. 1B). In each compartment, 90 

the various tectonic phases directly conditioned the sedimentary filling in regional 91 

depocenters. Consequently, due to the difference of the tectonic style, the 92 

sedimentary record is different in the Sergipe and the Alagoas Basins, resulting in a 93 

rather complex spatial distribution of chrono and lithostratigraphic units (Aquino & 94 

Lana, 1990) (Table 1). Nonetheless, the stratigraphic record in the Sergipe-Alagoas 95 

Basin is the most complete succession among the Brazilian continental margins, 96 

reflecting different phases of subsidence (Bizzi et al., 2003): (a) the Syneclise phase 97 

includes a Gondwanan intracratonic basin filled by Carboniferous glacial, subaquatic, 98 

and Permian deltaic-desert deposits; (b) the Pre-Rift Supersequence (Jurassic-99 

Berriasian) is characterized by crustal subsidence within the Afro-Brazilian 100 

Depression; (c) the Rift Supersequence (Berriasian to Aptian) reflects the stage of 101 

mechanical subsidence; and d) the Post-Rift Supersequence (Aptian) marks the 102 

onset and dominance of thermal subsidence, during which the first major marine 103 

incursion took place in the latest Aptian. The studied succession belongs to the Rift 104 

Supersequence. 105 



5  

Include Figure. 1 106 

Include Table. 1 107 

  The Pre-rift Supersequence is composed of lacustrine sediments of the 108 

Bananeiras Formation, fluvio-deltaic deposits of the Candeiro Formation, followed by 109 

the Serraria Formation and Caioba Sandstone that filled the depression with fluvial 110 

braided channel deposits. 111 

 According to Campos Neto et al (2007), the Rift Supersequence, which began 112 

142 Ma ago (Berriasian), is divided in different sub-sequences, from base to top 113 

called K10-K20, K34-K36, K38, and K40 (Feijó, 1994; Chiossi, 2005; Campos Neto 114 

et al., 2007; Borba, 2009).  The accumulation of the lacustrine deposits of the Feliz 115 

Deserto Formation (K10-K20) marks the beginning of the syn-rift filling. The focus of 116 

this study is the fluvio-deltaic and lacustrine deposits of the Barra de Itiúba and 117 

Penedo Formations (K34-K36) that overlie the Feliz Deserto Formation and 118 

correspond to the second (2) tectonic pulse of the syn-rift phase (Table 1), 119 

characterized by the establishment of graben and/or half-graben systems (Chagas et 120 

al., 2003). Historically, Schaller (1969) described the Feliz Deserto Formation as a 121 

succession of greenish shales interlayering with thin sandstones deposits that occurs 122 

in the basal part of the Barra de Itiúba Formation. Although these two units are 123 

lithologically identical, they were separated into two lithostratigraphic units due to the 124 

discovery of the “Pre-Aratu Unconformity”, identified by the absence of non-marine 125 

ostracod subzones of the “Rio da Serra” local age (Berriasian-Valanginian): Cypridea 126 

ventronodata Krommelbein 1962, Paracypridea maacki Krommelbein 1964, and 127 

Paracypridea bicallosa Krommelbein 1964 (Galm & Santos, 1994). Nowhere in the 128 

Sergipe-Alagoas Basin was encountered evidence of a continuous sedimentation 129 

from “Rio da Serra” to “Aratu” age, thus defining the regional character of the 130 

unconformity. According to Galm & Santos (1994), the ““Pre-Aratu Unconformity” 131 



6  

(PAU) represents an estimated 5-Ma hiatus in sedimentation, and it is related to rift 132 

propagation towards the Sergipe-Alagoas basin in the Valanginian to Hauterivian 133 

transition (Bueno, 2004). 134 

      The main depocenters are located in the Alagoas Sub-basin, where some areas 135 

such as the Furado field, located in the São Miguel dos Campos region, have 136 

accumulated around 2,000 meters of sediments (Borba, 2009). This region is mainly 137 

controlled by the border fault, with N60°E direction and at least 3,000 m offset 138 

(Borba, 2011). The proximal portion of sequence K34-K36 is largely dominated by 139 

the fluvial sandstones of the Penedo Formation, while the mid-distal area is 140 

represented by deltaic-lacustrine deposits of the Barra de Itiúba Formation. During 141 

that time interval, the ruptile efforts were mainly located in the Sergipe Sub-basin, 142 

where proximal, conglomeratic sandstones of the Rio Pitanga Formation were 143 

deposited very close to the active normal fault (Campos Neto et al., 2007). The end 144 

of the sequence (Upper Barremian) recorded the formation of a well-developed lake 145 

with maximum lake (base) level. Sequence K38 (Aptian), represented by the alluvial 146 

Pitanga and Poção Formations, deltaic Coqueiro Seco Formation, and distal, 147 

carbonate Morro do Chaves Formation that mark the beginning of the third (3) 148 

tectonic pulse, which increased in intensity throughout the basin (Campos Neto et al., 149 

2007). The last rift sequence K40 (Aptian) results of the fourth and latest tectonic 150 

pulse, when the tectonic intensity reached its maximum, is composed of sandy-151 

evaporitic sediments of the Maceió Formation, along with the Rio Pitanga and Poção 152 

Formations. According to Arienti (1996), this sequence reflects deposition in more 153 

arid conditions at the end of the Rift Supersequence. 154 

 The sedimentary filling of a rift system can be hierarchized in different order 155 

sequences. The entire rift evolution (pre-rift, rift and post-rift stages) comprises a first-156 

order sequence that can be sub-divided into second-order sequences (Table 1) that 157 



7  

corresponds to tectonic cycles during the rift evolution, separated by regional 158 

unconformities, and imprinting changes in depositional process in space and time. 159 

Based on core description in the Furado depocenters (Alagoas Sub-basin), Borba 160 

(2009, 2011) sub-divided the second-order K34-K36 into several third-order 161 

sequences that resulted from subsidence pulses during rift evolution, reflecting 162 

variation in accommodation. Borba (2009) sub-divided the K34-K36 sequence into 163 

nine third-order sequences (K34/10 to K36) that represent approximately 10.2 Ma of 164 

sedimentation (Table 2). These sequences show a general regressive trend, and 165 

they can be sub-divided into systems tracts (lowstand, transgressive, and highstand 166 

systems tracts). Each sequence begins with the deposition of fluvio-deltaic deposits, 167 

when sediment supply (S) is greater than accommodation space (A) produce by 168 

tectonic subsidence, resulting in a lowstand systems tract (A<S). The 169 

retrogradational trend that characterizes the transgressive systems tract led to the 170 

deposition of fine-grained prodelta sediments, culminating with lacustrine black 171 

shales (maximum flooding surface). This period of climax records a sedimentation in 172 

high accommodation space relative to sediment supply in a relatively humid climatic 173 

conditions, with a low sedimentary supply (A>S). The highstand systems tract, which 174 

ended the sequence, shows a well-defined progradational trend, generally thicker 175 

than other systems tracts that led to deposition and progradation of delta fronts 176 

during quiescence, during which progressively more proximal systems filled the 177 

accommodation (A<S). From beginning to end of the second-order K34-K36, the 178 

accumulation rate of sediments tended to increase during the development of the 179 

upper sequences (K35/40, K36), and proximal environments began to dominate. 180 

Include Table. 2 181 

3.  Study area and methods 182 



8  

      Two well cores (A and B) and thirteen outcrops were described in the Sergipe-183 

Alagoas Basin (Fig. 1). The studied section in well A (181 m thick) is located in the 184 

offshore Caioba field, southern Sergipe Sub-basin; in a raised area called “Atalaia 185 

High”. The well B (655 m thick) is located in the Furado depocenters, in São Miguel 186 

dos Campos platform, northern Alagoas sub-Basin. The thirteen stratigraphic 187 

sections measured in outcrops, with thicknesses variable between 5.4 and 29.7 m, 188 

are located along the São Francisco River and in the vicinity of the Japoatã High (Fig. 189 

1B). Facies and paleocurrent analyses of the latter were the subject of another 190 

publication (Courivaud et al., 2018, unpublished) and hence will not be discussed in 191 

detail, but rather only used to augment the interpretation of the studied well cores. 192 

The main subject of this paper is the proposal of a high-resolution sequence 193 

stratigraphy for the entire Barra de Itiúba Formation, using the continuous succession 194 

in well cores A and B. Studied wells were described in detail, resulting in the 195 

construction on lithologic logs at 1:100 scale. Facies analysis was based on 196 

lithofacies description following Miall (1978), including color, texture (grain size, 197 

sorting, and roundness), sedimentary structures, and fossil content, aided by gamma-198 

ray logs. The recognition of facies and facies associations, combined with the 199 

identification of major stratigraphic surfaces (maximum flooding surfaces, flooding 200 

surfaces, erosional surfaces, paleosols) allowed the identification of systems tracts 201 

and third-order stratigraphic sequences. 202 

 203 

4.  Facies analysis 204 

      Twenty-two lithofacies were identified in the studied outcrops and wells. They are 205 

summarized in Table 3 and illustrated in Figure 2. The Barra de Itiúba Formation is 206 

composed dominantly of quartzose sandstones (Sh, Sl, St, Sp, Sr, Sd, Sb), 207 

mudstones (Fr, Fd, Fl, Fb, Fm, P, C), sandy conglomerates (Gmm, Gd, Gi, Gl), and 208 



9  

subordinately heterolites (Hr, H). Texturally, the sandstones are very fine- to coarse-209 

grained (mostly very fine- to fine-grained), moderately- to well-sorted, with sub-210 

angular to rounded grains. Quartz granules are common in massive sandstones (Sm) 211 

and near the base of cross-bedded sets (St). Mudstones are commonly greenish and 212 

bioturbed (Fb), black-organic-rich (C), massive and gray (Fm), and, less commonly 213 

laminated (Fl) and fluidized (Fd). Conglomerates are massive, matrix-supported 214 

(Gmm), and trough cross-bedded (Gt), with sub-angular to sub-rounded granules to 215 

pebbles (mostly granules). Compositionally, the gravel is dominated by quartz and 216 

mud intraclasts, with occasionally feldspar and rock fragments. Well A is 217 

characterized by the dominance of coarse-grained lithofacies compared with Well B, 218 

in which the proportion between coarse- and fine-grained lithofacies is similar. 219 

Include Table. 3 220 

Include Figure. 2 221 

5.  Facies associations 222 

      The lithofacies identified were grouped into seven facies associations (F.A.): (1) 223 

Distributary channel; (2) Crevasse splay; (3) Interdistributary bay; (4) Proximal delta 224 

front; (5) Distal delta front; (6) Prodelta; and (7) Lacustrine. Facies associations 1 225 

through 3 are part of a delta plain, and 4 and 5 of a delta front. The vertical facies 226 

succession and the thickness of each facies association differs between wells A and 227 

B and the outcrop area. Representative vertical logs, along description and 228 

interpretation for each facies association in the wells and outcrop area is detailed in 229 

Fig. 3. 230 

5.1. Distributary channel F.A. 231 

      This facies association consists of several sandstone bodies up to 9 m thick 232 

(mainly plurimetric), composed of fine- to coarse-grained sandstones with trough 233 

cross-stratification (St), ripple cross-lamination (Sr) and, subordinately, low-angle 234 



10  

cross-stratification (Sl), massive (Sm), and fluidized (Sd). Trough cross-stratified and 235 

massive, matrix-supported (Gmm) conglomerates (Gt, Gmm) always occur at the 236 

base onto an erosive surface, which represent a key surface for the sequence 237 

stratigraphy interpretation (filling surface). When well-developed, this facies 238 

association locally forms a fining-upward succession, very commonly associated with 239 

crevasse splay and interdistributary bay facies associations.   240 

5.2. Crevasse splay F.A. 241 

      This facies association consists of coarse- to very fine-grained-sandstones, up to 242 

6 m thick, commonly intercalated with thin greenish, bioturbated (Fb) and ripple 243 

cross-laminated mudstones (Fr). The sandstones bodies are mostly formed by 244 

fluidized and bioturbated sandstones (Sd, Sb), alternated with massive (Sm), low-245 

angle cross-bedded (Sl) and ripple-cross laminated (Sr) sandstones. Bioturbated 246 

sandstones show vertical burrows, and, subordinately debris plants. Interbedding 247 

between fine sandstones and greenish mudstones represents the alternation of 248 

traction and suspension processes (Scherer et al., 2015). This F.A. commonly 249 

formed gradual coarsening-upward, progradational cycles. The plurimetric-thick 250 

packages of this facies association suggests a relatively fixed channel belt 251 

(meandering distributary channel?), and successive low-energy flows (Scherer et al., 252 

2015).  253 

5.3. Interdistributary bay 254 

      This facies association is mostly composed of homogeneous, bioturbated 255 

greenish mudstones (Fb), alternated with subordinate massive and fluidized greenish 256 

to gray mudstones (Fm, Fd). It has variable thickness between 0.3 and 3.5 m and 257 

usually associated with crevasse splay F.A. The mud packages commonly display 258 

oxide nodules (<2 cm) which suggest periods of subaerial exposure under oxidizing 259 

conditions. The dominance of thin, fine-grained facies in this F.A. indicate low 260 



11  

sedimentation rates in a low-energy environment. Frequently, vertical succession 261 

shows color variations (greenish to reddish-yellowish), characterizing the 262 

predominance of flooding and decantation (greenish) and overflow phases (reddish-263 

yellowish) in the deltaic plain. 264 

5.4. Proximal delta front 265 

  This facies association consists of coarse- to fine-grained sandstones, up to 4 m 266 

thick, well-sorted. Sand bodies are mostly composed of trough cross-bedded (St), 267 

convoluted and deformed sandstones (Sd), alternating with subordinate horizontal 268 

laminated (Sh) and massive sandstones (Sm). The occurrence of stacked sandy 269 

bodies with tractive structures, locally forming well-defined coarsening-upward 270 

cycles, superimposed onto fine-grained distal delta front deposits, suggests 271 

deposition and progradation of a proximal delta front system. The coarsest and 272 

better-sorted sand deposits, with mostly unidirectional (measured in outcrops area) 273 

tractive structures (Sh, St), were interpreted as river-dominated distributary-mouth 274 

bar deposits, formed by riverine inflow into a low-energy setting, whereas fluidized 275 

sandstones (Sd) represent large quantities of sediment transported from the mouth 276 

bar to deeper water, by rapid flow deceleration in a short period of time (Battacharya, 277 

2010). In term of sedimentary volume deposited, this relatively proximal deltaic 278 

environment represents large proportion of sedimentation during the filled phase.   279 

5.5. Distal delta front 280 

      This facies association, up to 7.5 m thick, is composed of medium- to fine-grained 281 

sandstones alternated with siltstones and heterolites. Sand bodies mostly consist of 282 

very-fine grained, bioturbated (Sb) and deformed (Sd) sandstones, occasionally 283 

alternated with ripple-cross laminated (Sr) and massive (Sm) sandstones. Locally the 284 

sandstones are intercalated with ripple-cross laminated heterolites (Hr), suggesting 285 

variation in flow energy, with periods of gravitational settling by suspension. Metric 286 



12  

sandstone/siltstone alternations commonly form poorly-defined coarsening-upward 287 

cycles in a progradational trend, reflecting smaller- scale (seasonal?) changes in river 288 

discharge. Despite the dominance of fine-grained lithologies, the 289 

sandstone/mudstone ratio is much higher than in the prodelta deposits, which was 290 

the main criterion to differentiate distal delta front and prodelta facies associations in 291 

the studied wells. This distal deltaic environment generally represents initial phases 292 

of filling in depositional sequences identified in wells. 293 

5.6. Prodelta 294 

      This facies association consists of siltstones to mudstones, with variable 295 

thickness between 0.5to 4.5 m, composed mainly of greenish to gray, massive (Fm) 296 

and weakly bioturbated (Fb) mudstones, occasionally alternated with fluidized (Fd) 297 

and laminated (Fl) mudstones. Rarely mudstones are intercalated with cross-298 

laminated sandstones to siltstones (Sr, Fr), suggesting episodic increases in 299 

discharge by the feeder river. Prodelta mudstones show an abundance of soft-300 

sediment deformation features, such as load structures, and dewatering-related 301 

features (Battacharya and MacEachern, 2009). The predominance of fine-grained 302 

deposits points to deposition in low-energy environment. The blackish color and the 303 

limited bioturbation in relatively thick-metric mudstones is interpreted as gravitational 304 

settling in a dysoxic, deep water body. 305 

5.7. Lacustrine 306 

      This facies association, up 9.8 m thick, consists of homogeneous black, organic-307 

rich mudstone (C), intercalated with dark gray massive mudstones (Fm), and, 308 

subordinately, laminated gray mudstones (Fl). Locally the mudstones contain 309 

bivalves and ostracods, and thin laminated sandstones (Sl), deposited by density 310 

flows, are present. This facies association, generally plurimetric, is interpreted as 311 

suspension settling in a deep, anoxic, and perennial lake. 312 



13  

Include Figure. 3 313 

6.  Sequence stratigraphy framework 314 

      In the last 30 years, many authors have attempted to use the sequence 315 

stratigraphic models of passive-margin basin to understand the evolution and the 316 

sedimentary filling in different types of basins, despite fundamental differences in 317 

terms of the mechanisms controlling the tectono-stratigraphy of these basins.  318 

      Depositional sequences in passive margin begin with a forced regression (base-319 

level fall) that causes subaerial exposure, and erosion, with the establishment of 320 

‘lowstand fans’ in the deeper part of the basin. Then, a base-level rise characterizes 321 

a retrogradational trend with a positive accommodation and a low sediment supply, 322 

inducing the progressive establishment of deeper-water environments, such as 323 

marine carbonates and black shales. The accommodation space created by rising 324 

sea level is then progressively filled by sediments from the continental wedge, in a 325 

relatively stable interplay between accommodation and sediment supply (aggradation 326 

or normal progradation). The succession of these depositional trends, represented by 327 

variations between rates of accommodation (positive and negative) and sediment 328 

supply (low or high), allows sub-divisions of the depositional sequence into lowstand 329 

(negative accommodation, high sediment supply), transgressive (positive 330 

accommodation, low sediment supply) and highstand (balance between 331 

accommodation and sediment supply) systems tract. 332 

 In contrast with passive-margin basins where cyclic sea level fluctuations control 333 

the sedimentary architecture, accommodation in rift basins is dominantly created, or 334 

lost, as a result of tectonic activity (mechanical subsidence). Martins-Neto & 335 

Catuneanu (2009, in press) proposed a model to provide a better understanding of 336 

the evolution and the stratigraphic record in rift basins. During syn-rift continental 337 

sedimentation (such as the Barra de Itiúba Formation), subsidence with a short stage 338 



14  

of rapid creation of accommodation is mainly linked to pulses of extension and border 339 

normal-fault reactivation, although climatic controls and  lake base-level fluctuations 340 

may operate at high frequency on the stratigraphic cyclicity. According to this model, 341 

a complete depositional sequence in rift basins begins with a short retrogradational 342 

cycle (transgressive succession, underfilled phase) in response to the tectonic pulse 343 

of extensional subsidence, followed by a longer progradational trend during the 344 

tectonic quiescence corresponding to the “filled phase”, when sediment supply 345 

consumes the available accommodation space created during the extensional 346 

subsidence. Stratigraphically, it results in a thin fining-upward succession (shallow-347 

water), followed by a thicker coarsening-upward succession during the filled phase. 348 

In the later stages, the available accommodation space can be fully filled by coastal 349 

deltaic deposits, and erosive distributary channels associated with proximal delta 350 

plain deposits (crevasse splay, interdistributary bay, paleosols) forming the overfilled 351 

phase. This erosive transition reflects the shift from “filled” to “overfilled” phase. 352 

 In our sequences interpreted and adapted (Fig. 4) according to this model, the 353 

identification of the "filling surface” (FS), usually marked by the appearance of the 354 

first thick distributary channels, was chosen as the transition marker between "filling 355 

phase" and the last “overfilled phase”, and usually represents the beginning of the 356 

“overfilled systems tract” (OST) which conclude the sequence (SB). It was also 357 

chosen to call the "filled systems tract" (FST), which starts already from the maximum 358 

flood surface (SIM), generally as the beginning of delta progradation in prodelta-359 

lacustrine environment, due to the difficulty of locating exactly where accommodation 360 

is in balance with sediment supply (sensu Martins-Neto & Catuneanu, 2009, in 361 

press). 362 

Depending of the sequence scale order (2
th

/3
th 

order), a new tectonic pulse marks 363 

the initiation of a new rift sequence by the creation of a consequent “instantaneous” 364 



15  

accommodation space (Martins-Neto & Catuneanu, 2009, in press), leading to a 365 

change from an “overfilled” to a new “underfilled” phase. 366 

Include Figure. 4 367 

The sequence stratigraphic model proposed by Martins-Neto & Catuneanu (2009, 368 

in press) is the one that best applies to understanding the stratigraphy record of the 369 

syn-rift Barra de Itiúba Formation. In well sections (Fig. 5, 6), seven complete 3
th

-370 

order depositional sequences can be identified, mostly composed of unferfilled, filled, 371 

and overfilled systems tracts (sensu Martins-Neto & Catuneanu, 2009, in press), 372 

recognized and correlated across the study area (Fig. 7). Using ostracod biozones 373 

and the recognition of a regional erosive surface formed by coarse-grained 374 

sandstones onto fine-grained lacustrine deposits (Borba, 2011),  the identification  of 375 

the “Pre-Aratu Unconformity” (PAU) in well A (1958,70m) and well B (1624, 40m) 376 

mark the lithostratigraphic transition between the underlying Feliz Deserto Formation 377 

(Neocomian, Rio da Serra local stage) and the Barra de Itiúba Formation (Barremian, 378 

Aratu to Buracica local stages), related to the second major tectonic pulse (2
th 

order) 379 

in the Sergipe-Alagoas rift succession. 380 

Include Figure. 5 381 

Include Figure. 6 382 

6.1. Sequence 1 383 

This sequence, 10 to 34 m thick, represents the onset of the second pulse of 384 

tectonic. In the Sergipe sub-basin (well A), the sequence is bounded at the base by a 385 

sharp erosional unconformity that separates fine-grained lacustrine deposits of the 386 

Feliz Deserto Formation (PAU) from coarse-grained sandstones deposited by 387 

distributary channels, the first deposits of the Barra de Itiúba Formation. The 388 

sequence in only represented by the progradational trends (FST, OST) and it shows 389 



16  

a thin coarsening-upward succession composed of interbedded crevasse splay and 390 

interdistributary bay deposits. In the Alagoas sub-basin (well B), the underfilled 391 

systems tract was preserved, with the deposition of thin lacustrine deposits, rapidly 392 

covered by prograding distal delta front deposits which represent the beginning of the 393 

filled phase. The overfilled phase begins with the deposition of erosive thick 394 

conglomerates of distributary channel (FS, 1615.20 m), probably from proximal 395 

deltaic plain, followed and intercalated with crevasse splay in middle part of the 396 

succession.  397 

6.2. Sequence 2 398 

 Sequence 2, 55 m to 108 m thick, begins with a new retrogradational trend (UST) 399 

in which deltaic to lacustrine deposits overlie the flooding surface (SB 1), in response 400 

to the rapid subsidence created by a new tectonic pulse. In the Alagoas sub-basin, 401 

lacustrine deposits directly overlie the flooding surface, suggesting fast and high 402 

creation of accommodation space. The filled systems tract forms the bulk of the 403 

sequence, with a thick, well-defined progradational coarsening-upward succession 404 

(delta progradation) during the filled phase. This coarsening-upward succession is 405 

very well represented in the Sergipe sub-basin (well A), with the vertical evolution 406 

from distal (lacustrine, prodelta) deposits to distal delta front deposits (fluidized, fine-407 

grained sandstones), overlain by medium to fine-grained trough-cross stratified 408 

sandstones (proximal delta front). The overfilled phase completes the sequence, with 409 

the deposition of erosive distributary channel associated with crevasse splay 410 

deposits, onto delta front deposits. 411 

6.3. Sequence 3 412 

This sequence, 27 m to 123 m thick, leads off with a short underfilled systems 413 

tract represented by the deposition of organic-rich lacustrine mudstones covering the 414 



17  

flooding surface (SB 2). During the filled phase, the succession passes upward to 415 

greenish bioturbated prodelta mudstones and delta front sandstones. 416 

In the Sergipe portion, the filled phase, relatively thinner, is covered by thick 417 

erosive distributary channel deposits interlayed with crevasse splay and 418 

interdistributary bay deposits formed during a relatively early overfilled phase. In the 419 

Alagoas portion (well B), the succession is thicker and shows a slight coarsening-420 

upward succession, overlain by thin erosive distributary channel deposits interlayered 421 

with delta and prodelta deposits. 422 

Thus, it appears that the magnitude of tectonic pulse has a greater in the Alagoas 423 

portion, with the creation of more accommodation (related to tectonic pulse) than in 424 

the Sergipe portion. Furthermore, in contrast with well A, the overfilled systems tract 425 

succession in the Alagoas portion is poorly developed, composed by alternating 426 

distal deposits (prodelta, distal delta front) with proximal delta plain deposits, which 427 

suggests that the progradational phase (FST) did not fill completely the available 428 

accommodation space. This can be explained by a fast base-level rise (strong pulse 429 

of tectonic subsidence) followed by prolonged tectonic stillstand during the tectonic 430 

quiescence (Martins Neto & Catuneanu, 2009, in press).  431 

6.4. Sequence 4 432 

 With a thickness of 24.5 to 74.5 m, this sequence begins suddenly with a 433 

retrogradational trend with the deposition of thin lacustrine mudstones overlying the 434 

flooding surface. 435 

In Sergipe sub-basin, the transition is less abrupt, with the deposition of trough-436 

bedded and massive delta front sandstones overlain by thin lacustrine deposits. A 437 

well-defined coarsening-upward succession, mostly composed of bioturbated, 438 

massive distal delta front sandstones, overlain by trough cross-bedded proximal delta 439 

front sandstones (mouth-bars), represents the filled phase. 440 



18  

In the Alagoas portion, the gamma-ray profile suggests a filled phase composted 441 

of interlayered prodelta and distal to proximal delta front deposits. Overlying this 442 

sucession, an abrupt drop in gamma-ray (at depth 1311 m) marks probably the onset 443 

of the overfilled phase, with the erosive base of a thick amalgamated distributary 444 

channel. In Sergipe, a sharp erosive surface (FS 4) at the base of trough cross-445 

bedded conglomerates, overlain by thick amalgamated distributary channel, crevasse 446 

splay, and interdistributary bay deposits, points to a change from the filled to 447 

overfilled phase. 448 

6.5. Sequence 5 449 

 This sequence is characterized by a remarkable difference in sequence thickness 450 

between the two wells. In the Sergipe-sub basin, the very thin sequence (11.9 m 451 

thick) shows a retrogradational trend, overlain by only 2 m thick proximal delta front 452 

deposits that signals the onset the progradational depositional trend. This succession 453 

is followed by thick erosive, massive matrix-supported conglomerates (FS 5). The 454 

overfilled phase dominates the depositional sequence, which suggests that the 455 

creation of accommodation produced by regional tectonic subsidence (pulse) began 456 

to decrease. In contrast, with a thickness of 95.5 m, in the Alagoas portion the 457 

depositional sequence is relatively complete. Overlying the flooding surface, the 458 

gamma-ray data shows a retrogradational trend that reach its maximum (MFS) in an 459 

unrecovered core interval. Overlying the maximum flooding surface, a coarsening-460 

upward succession, possibly delta front deposits, characterizes the filled systems 461 

tract. At last, thick assemblages of erosive and amalgamated distributary channel 462 

sand bodies, interlayered with thin crevasse splay deposits, represent the overfilled 463 

phase (OST). 464 

6.6. Sequence 6 465 



19  

This sequence shows many similitudes with the previous sequence. While the 466 

overfilled phase clearly dominates a very thin sequence (6.1 m) in the Sergipe 467 

portion, the Alagoas portion shows a thick, complete sequence with a thicker 468 

succession deposited in the filled phase, indicating a longer period of quiescence. 469 

Overlying the flooding surface (SB 5), distal delta deposits covered by prodelta 470 

heterolites define the slightly retrogradational trend in the Sergipe portion, abruptly 471 

covered by massive and low-angle cross-bedded sandstones interpreted as part of 472 

proximal delta front deposits (filled systems tract). A 40 cm thick layer, intensely 473 

broken and oxidized, with green and red concretions, and indistinctive bioturbation, 474 

forms the top of the sequence (ovrfilled systems tract). This horizon, interpreted as a 475 

paleosol (1814,60 m), represents a long hiatus with subaerial exposure, suggesting 476 

that at that time, the basin was completely overfilled, with no more sediment input 477 

from the sedimentary source. 478 

The Alagoas succession, 90 m thick, shows an opposite trend. The sequence 479 

begins with rapid creation of accommodation, with a thin retrogradational succession 480 

formed by lacustrine and prodelta mudstones overlying the flooding surface. The 481 

maximum flooding surface, identified at depth of 1181 m in thick lacustrine 482 

mudstones, possibly corresponds to the datum in the 3th-order K35/20 sequence, 483 

identified by Borba (2011). The filled sytems tract (57.5 m thick) is mostly composed 484 

of gray and black mudstones, interlayered with thin, bioturbated very-fine sandstones 485 

deposited in distal delta fronts. The common presence of turbidites interbedded with 486 

these deposits suggests a fairly high-slope basin margin and probably high 487 

accommodation available, and may mean that sedimentation in that part of the basin 488 

was probably still under underfilled conditions (A>>S). Overlying this poorly 489 

developed filled phase, the occurrence of very thin, trough cross-bedded 490 

conglomerates, slightly erosive, marks the beginning of the overfilled phase, also little 491 



20  

pronounced. During the overfilled systems tract, thin conglomerates are interlayered 492 

with fine-grained, distal delta front and prodelta deposits. This suggests that the 493 

basin was potentially still in the filled phase, under more humid conditions, and that 494 

repetitive incursion of distributary channels resulted from minor-scale climatic 495 

changes. Isotopic data indicated that sedimentation during the Barremian (Buracica 496 

local stage) took place under more humid conditions (Chiossi, 1997), which could 497 

partially explain the predominance of distal mudstones and a poorly developed 498 

progradacional filled-overfilled succession. 499 

6.7. Sequence 7 500 

This sequence corresponds to the last 3th-order sequence of the Barra de Itiúba 501 

Formation. Its thickness varies between 12.3 and 98 m. The basal flooding surface 502 

(SB 6) is covered by a retrogradational succession formed by gray mudstones in the 503 

Sergipe portion and black lacustrine deposits in the Alagoas portion, suggesting 504 

renewed intensity of tectonic subsidence in the Sergipe sub-basin, in comparison 505 

with the two previous sequences (low to moderately intensity of tectonic pulse). 506 

Consequently, the progradational trend that characterizes the filled systems tract is 507 

thicker and better developed, formed by distal delta front, bioturbated sandstones 508 

interlayered with prodelta, massive mudstones. 509 

In the Alagoas sub-basin, the filled phase is mostly composed of prodelta 510 

mudstones, with common distal deltaic incursions. Overlying this interval, the 511 

occurrence of highly erosive, amalgamated distributary channel deposits, associated 512 

with crevasse splay and interdistributary bay deposits, signals the predominance of 513 

the overfilled phase, completing the sequence. In Sergipe, the overfilled phase began 514 

with a highly erosive, trough cross-bedded conglomerate, followed by oxidized, low 515 

angle cross-bedded sandstones with centimetric coal clasts, interpreted as crevasse 516 

splay deposits. 517 



21  

6.8. Sequence 8 518 

This sequence is interpreted as the lithostratigraphic transition between the Barra 519 

de Itiúba Formation and the Penedo Formation in the Alagoas portion, and the Rio 520 

Pitanga Formation in the Sergipe portion (Borba, 2009, 2011). This incomplete 521 

sequence was detailed through core description only in the retrogradacional 522 

succession (well A). Abruptly overlying the flooding surface are gray to black prodelta 523 

and lacustrine mudstones.  Above the maximum flooding surface, the gamma-ray 524 

signature (not includin in this work) in the two sections suggests that the rate of 525 

sedimentation and occurrence of coarse-grained deposits tend to increase. In 526 

Sergipe, this interval was interpreted as a thick succession of distributary channel 527 

and fluvial-alluvial channels deposits (Rio Pitanga Formation), and as amalgamated 528 

distributary channel deposits in the Alagoas portion (Penedo Formation). 529 

Include Figure. 7 530 

7. Tectono-stratigraphic synthesis 531 

Sequence 1 represents the onset of the second tectonic pulse (2
th 

order) across 532 

the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin. Its succession is dominated by overfilled systems tract 533 

(OST), characterized by the predominance of coarse-grained deposits, principally 534 

composed of erosive distributary channel deposits. This suggests that the available 535 

accommodation space created during the tectonic pulse is not even sufficient to 536 

“accommodate” the sediment supply, probably produced in great part from the border 537 

fault. Unlike the first sequence, Sequence 2 shows a well-defined retrogradational, 538 

with deposition of lacustrine sediments onto the flooding surface, suggesting rapid 539 

creation of accommodation space with increasing tectonic activity. The filled phase is 540 

well developed, forming the bulk of this sequence, composed of a coarsening-upward 541 

succession of prodelta deposits progressively covered by delta front sandstones. The 542 



22  

overfilled phase begins with occurrence of erosive distributary channel deposits (FS 543 

2) interlayed with crevasse splay and interdistributary bay deposits.  544 

Deposition of Sequence 3 began with a very short retrogradational trend with the 545 

abrupt accumulation of deep water black, organic-rich mudstones that cover the 546 

flooding surface, suggesting a stronger tectonic pulse linked to increasing tectonic 547 

subsidence. The sedimentary succession that represents the filled phase shows a 548 

slight coarsening-upward trend, composed of prodelta and distal delta front deposits. 549 

In the Alagoas portion, the poorly-developed overfilled systems tract suggests that 550 

the available accommodation space was not completely filled, contrary to the Sergipe 551 

portion, where the overfilled phase was well developed. This suggests that the 552 

tectonic pulses has a greater role in the Alagoas portion, with longer periods of 553 

tectonic quiescence between them. 554 

Sequence 4 is similar to the previous sequence. It began with a short 555 

retrogradational trend that led to the accumulation of lacustrine deposits, followed by 556 

a well-defined, thicker progradational trend. The thick filled systems tract in the 557 

Sergipe portion points to renewed tectonic activity with border fault reactivation in the 558 

Sergipe portion. Meanwhile, in the Alagoas portion, the tectonic activity seems to 559 

have stabilized, with less creation of accommodation, as indicated by the coarser-560 

grain progradational trend (filled phase) and thick distributary channel deposits of the 561 

overfilled phase. 562 

There is some evidence of tectonic changes during the deposition of Sequence 5. 563 

While in the Alagoas portion this sequence clearly shows rapid creation of 564 

accommodation by tectonic pulse, followed by a thick progradational succession 565 

(filled and overfilled phase), in the Sergipe portion the sedimentary succession clearly 566 

shows decreasing intensity of the tectonic activity. The overfilled systems tract 567 



23  

predominates, with a very short filled phase covered by thick erosive conglomerates 568 

(FS 5), suggesting low accommodation relative to sediment supply (A<<S). 569 

This general trend is confirmed during the deposition of Sequence 6. In the 570 

Sergipe portion, following the deposition of very thin prodelta heterolites, the filled 571 

phase is largely composed of massive, proximal delta front sandstones, covered by 572 

paleosol horizon, indicating that the basin was completely overfilled and subject to 573 

subaerial exposure with long-term erosion (with probably high-frequency climatic 574 

contribution, in more arid conditions). The Alagoas portion, on the other hand, shows 575 

evidence of increasing tectonic activity. A very thin retrogradational succession is 576 

rapidly covered by a thick, finer-grained progradational succession (filled phase), 577 

followed by thin, poorly-developed distributary channel deposits interlayered with 578 

distal delta deposits, suggesting an augmentation of available accommodation space 579 

by tectonic pulse. 580 

The last complete sequence (7) points to renewed tectonic activity (probably of 581 

moderate intensity) in the Sergipe portion, as indicated by the deposition of prodelta 582 

mudstones, followed by a thicker and more better developed filled systems tract, 583 

covered by thin and highly erosive distributary channel and crevasse splay deposits. 584 

In the Alagoas portion, the tectonic regime seems to have been even stronger, but 585 

with a tendency to decrease. The filled phase is thinner, mostly composed of distal 586 

delta deposits. The following overfilled systems tract predominates, with the 587 

deposition of interlayered beds of thick conglomerates and fine-grained crevasse 588 

splay associated with interdistributary bay deposits. Compared with previous 589 

sequences, the dominance of overfilled phase in Sequence 7 is probably due to a 590 

combination of tectonic and climatic effects. Sedimentation during the late stages of 591 

rift evolution in the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin is probably controlled by a decrease of 592 



24  

tectonic activity (less accommodation space creation), combined with more humid 593 

conditions (increase of clastic contributions) (Chiossi, 1997; Borba, 2011). 594 

8. Conclusion 595 

1. The Barra de Itiúba Formation records the deposition of deltaic and lacustrine 596 

sediments accumulated in the syn-rift Sergipe-Alagoas Basin during the second 597 

extensional pulse (2
th
 order) of basin evolution. Facies analysis in wells and outcrops 598 

allowed the recognition of 22 facies, grouped into seven facies associations that 599 

characterize different depositional environments: (i) distributary channel (braided and 600 

meandering), (ii) crevasse splay, (iii) interdistributary bay, (iv) proximal delta front, (v) 601 

distal delta front, (vi) prodelta, and (vii) lacustrine. 602 

2. The application of Martins-Neto & Catuneanu (2009, in press) rift sequence 603 

stratigraphic model in the two well sections allowed the identification of seven 604 

complete 3
th

 order depositional sequences bounded by flooding surface (sequence 605 

boundary). 606 

3. All the sequences initiated with a relatively thin retrogradational succession 607 

representing the ‘instantaneous’ creation of accommodation linked to 3
th

 order 608 

tectonic pulse (underfilled phase, A>S). Then, a long progradational trend (filled 609 

systems tract), describing a coarsening-upward deltaic succession, is filling the 610 

available accommodation (filled phase, A<S then A>S in proximal delta front). 611 

Starting onto the “filling surface” (FS), the last portion (overfilled systems tract), 612 

composed of erosive amalgamated distributary channels associated with crevasse 613 

splay and interdistributary bay deposits, characterize the “overfilled phase”, when the 614 

accommodation space is not sufficient relative to sediment supply. 615 

4. The Sergipe portion is thinner (181m thick), mostly composed of proximal deposits 616 

(delta front, deltaic plain), and was deposited during a relatively low local tectonic 617 

regime. In contrast, the thicker Alagoas portion (655 m), mostly composed of distal 618 



25  

deposits (lacustrine to delta front), show evidences of higher tectonic subsidence with 619 

high rate of accommodation, combined with sedimentation in more humid conditions. 620

Table 3. Summary of the lithofacies identified in the Barra de Itiúba Formation. Lithofacies with * were 

described only in outcrops. 

Facies Description Interpretation 
Gmm Massive, matrix-supported conglomerates, poorly sorted; sub-angular 

grain; dominant quartz granules (subordinate feldspar and rock 
fragments); incipient gradation and erosive base; 1.6 to 10 m thick 
beds. 

Plastic debris flow (high-strength, viscous) 
(Miall, 1996). 

*Gd Matrix-supported conglomerates with deformed sandstones blocks 
(up to 4.9 m across); rafts of heterolites and highly-deformed 
mudstones; 2 m thick bed. 

Deformation of semi-consolidated sediments by 
gravitational instability (Anketell et al., 1970; 
Selker, 1993; Moretti et al., 1999). 

*Gi Intraformational, clast-supported conglomerates; very fine sandstone 
matrix; mud intraclasts (<2 cm); 0.4 m thick bed. 

Fragmented mud cracks incorporated to 
tractive flows (Glennie, 1970); or collapsed 
banks by hyperconcentrated flows (Coleman, 
1969). 

*Gl Bioclastic, matrix- to clast-supported conglomerates with low-angle 
cross-stratification; bone fragments (<3 cm) and mud intraclasts (<2 
cm); 0.15 to 0.5 m thick beds. 

Humback or washed-out dunes (transitional 
flow regime) (Miall, 1996).  

Gt Clast-supported conglomerates with trough cross-stratification; sub-
angular grains; dominant quartz and feldspar granules (rare rock 
fragments); 0.1 to 2 m thick sets. 

3D gravel dunes (Rust, 1978; Todd, 1996). 

Sh 
 

Fine- to medium-grained sandstones with horizontal lamination; 
moderately- to well-sorted; 0.2 to 1 m thick beds. 
 

Planar-bedded deposits originated via upper 
flow regime (Miall, 1977; Best and Bridge, 
1992; Marshall, 2000). 

Sl Fine- to coarse-grained sandstones with low angle cross-stratification; 
moderately- to well-sorted; 0.2 to 0.9 m thick beds.  

Washed-out dunes and humpack dunes 
(transition between subcritical and 
supercritical flows) (Harms et al., 1982). 

St Fine- to coarse-grained sandstones with trough cross-stratification; 
poorly- to well-sorted; sub-angular grains; Dominant quartz granules; 
locally erosive base; 0.15 to 2.8 m thick sets. 

3D subaqueous sandy dunes deposited via 
lower flow regime (Harms et al.; 1982; Miall, 
1996; Collinson et al.; 2006). 

*Sp Fine- to medium-grained sandstones with planar cross-stratification; 
moderately- to well-sorted; 0.4 to 1.2 m thick sets. 

2D subaqueous sandy dunes deposited via 
lower flow regime (Harms et al.; 1982; Miall, 
1996; Collinson et al.; 2006). 

Sr Very fine- to medium-grained sandstones with ripple cross-lamination 
(subcritical to critical climbing angle); moderately- to well-sorted; 
centimeter-thick sets forming up to 2.4 m thick cosets.  

Small-scale ripple migration in unidirectional 
lower flow regime (Allen, 1963; Miall, 1996). 

Sd 
 
 

Fine- to medium-grained sandstones with convoluted lamination and 
flame structure; moderately- to well-sorted; relicts of laminated mud 
common; 0.1 to 5.8 m thick beds. 

Deposits deformed by fluidization.  

Sb Very fine- to medium- grained sandstones with horizontal and vertical 
burrows; well sorted; 5.9 to 20 m thick beds. 

Deposition deformed by bioturbation. 

Sm Fine-to medium-grained, massive sandstones; locally sub-angular 
quartz granules; 0.2 to 2 m thick beds. 

Deposition of hyperconcentrated flows, 
fluidization or intensive bioturbation (Todd, 
1989; Miall, 1978, 1996). 

H Heterolites with linsen bedding formed by intercalation of massive 
siltstones and very fine-grained sandstones; 0.1 to 1.6 m thick beds. 

Variation of energy levels, with gravitational 
settling from suspension alternating with 
deposition from hyperconcentrated flows 
(Miall, 1996). 

Hr Heterolites with linsen bedding and ripple cross-lamination 
(subcritical climbing angle); often bioturbation; formed by 
intercalation of massive silt-mudstones and very fine- to fine-grained 
sandstones; 0.4 to 2.2 m thick beds. 

Variation of energy levels, with gravitational 
settling from suspension, alternating with 
deposition from ripple migration under 
unidirectional lower flow regime. 

Fr 
 
 

Siltstones- to very fine-grained sandstones with ripple cross-
lamination (critical climbing angle); often bioturbation, moderately- to 
well-sorted; 0.15 to 1.5 m thick beds.  

Low-energy tractive currents (Miall, 1977). 

Fd Siltstones- to very fine-grained sandstones with convolute lamination; 
common load structures and bioturbation; 0.2 cm to 2.9 m thick beds. 

Fine deposits deformed by fluidization.  

Fl 
 

Mudstones to siltstones with horizontal lamination; yellowish to gray; 
0.15 to 2.7 m thick beds. 

Suspension settling.  
Zero flow velocity (Rogers & Astin, 1991). 

Fb Greenish to gray bioturbated mudstones, often convolute lamination; 
0.1 cm to 3.5 m thick beds. 

Suspension settling, deformed by bioturbation. 

Fm 
 

Massive mudstones; greenish to gray, rarely yellowish; 0.15 to 3.9 m 
thick beds. 

Suspension settling.  
Zero flow velocity (Miall, 1977). 

C Black, organic-rich mudstones; often coal fragments (<4 cm); 
slickensides, often ostracode-rich levels; 0.2 to 5 m thick beds. 

Suspension settling of sediments under anoxic 
or poorly-oxidized conditions (Chakraborty and 
Sarkar, 2005; Foix et al., 2013). 

P 
 

Mudstones with concretions, root traces, with high oxidized level; 40 
cm thick bed. 

Chemical precipitation in long time-prolonged 
sub-aerial exposure condition (Retallack, 
2001).
